Takes a fully pathed string and eliminates relative pathing (eg: annihilates ".." with the adjacent directory). Assumes all slashes have been converted to TEXT('/'). For example, takes the string: BaseDirectory/SomeDirectory/../SomeOtherDirectory/Filename.ext and converts it to: BaseDirectory/SomeOtherDirectory/Filename.ext
Takes an "Unreal" pathname and converts it to a platform filename.
Converts a relative path name to a fully qualified name relative to the process BaseDir().

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.AActor.GetActorEyesViewPoint(UnrealEngine.FVector@,UnrealEngine.FRotator@)
member.summary: Returns the point of view of the actor. Note that this doesn't mean the camera, but the 'eyes' of the actor. For example, for a Pawn, this would define the eye height location, and view rotation (which is different from the pawn rotation which has a zeroed pitch component). A camera first person view will typically use this view point. Most traces (weapon, AI) will be done from this view point. @param OutLocation - location of view point @param OutRotation - view rotation of actor.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bHidden
member.summary: Allows us to only see this Actor in the Editor, and not in the actual game. @see SetActorHiddenInGame()

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bNetTemporary
member.summary: If true, when the actor is spawned it will be sent to the client but receive no further replication updates from the server afterwards.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bNetStartup
member.summary: If true, this actor was loaded directly from the map, and for networking purposes can be addressed by its full path name

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bOnlyRelevantToOwner
member.summary: If true, this actor is only relevant to its owner. If this flag is changed during play, all non-owner channels would need to be explicitly closed.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bAlwaysRelevant
member.summary: Always relevant for network (overrides bOnlyRelevantToOwner).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bReplicateMovement
P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bTearOff
member.summary: If true, this actor is no longer replicated to new clients, and is "torn off" (becomes a ROLE_Authority) on clients to which it was being replicated. @see TornOff()

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bExchangedRoles
member.summary: Whether we have already exchanged Role/RemoteRole on the client, as when removing then re-adding a streaming level. Causes all initialization to be performed again even though the actor may not have actually been reloaded.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bPendingNetUpdate

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bNetLoadOnClient

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bNetUseOwnerRelevancy

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.bBlockInput

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AActor.AttachmentReplication

member.summary: If true, this actor should search for an owned camera component to view through when used as a view target.

M:UnrealEngine.ACharacter.StopJumping
member.summary: Stop the character from jumping on the next update. Call this from an input event (such as a button 'up' event) to cease applying jump Z-velocity. If this is not called, then jump z-velocity will be applied until JumpMaxHoldTime is reached.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.ACharacter.Jump
member.summary: Make the character jump on the next update. If you want your character to jump according to the time that the jump key is held, then you can set JumpKeyHoldTime to some non-zero value. Make sure in this case to call StopJumping() when you want the jump's z-velocity to stop being applied (such as on a button up event), otherwise the character will carry on receiving the velocity until JumpKeyHoldTime is reached.

member.summary: Jump key Held Time. This is the time that the player has held the jump key, in seconds.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.ACharacter.JumpMaxHoldTime
member.summary: The max time the jump key can be held. Note that if StopJumping() is not called before the max jump hold time is reached, then the character will carry on receiving vertical velocity. Therefore it is usually best to call StopJumping() when jump input has ceased (such as a button up event).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.ACharacter.JumpMaxCount
member.summary: The max number of jumps the character can perform. Note that if JumpMaxHoldTime is non zero and StopJumping is not called, the player may be able to perform and unlimited number of jumps. Therefore it is usually best to call StopJumping() when jump input has ceased (such as a button up event).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.ACharacter.JumpCurrentCount
member.summary: Tracks the current number of jumps performed. This is incremented in CheckJumpInput, used in CanJump_Implementation, and reset in OnMovementModeChanged. When providing overrides for these methods, it's recommended to either manually increment / reset this value, or call the Super:: method.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.ACharacter.bJumpMaxCountExceeded
member.summary: Whether or not the JumpMaxCount value has been exceeded. This is set in CheckJumpInput, used in CanJump_Implementation, and reset in OnMovementModeChanged. When providing overrides for these methods, it's recommended to either manually set / reset this value, or call the Super:: method.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.AController
member.summary: Controllers are non-physical actors that can possess a Pawn to control its actions. PlayerControllers are used by human players to control pawns, while AIControllers implement the artificial intelligence for the pawns they control. Controllers take control of a pawn using their Possess() method, and relinquish control of the pawn by calling UnPossess(). Controllers receive notifications for many of the events occurring for the Pawn they are controlling. This gives the controller the opportunity to implement the behavior in response to this event, intercepting the event and superseding the Pawn's default behavior. ControlRotation (accessed via GetControlRotation()), determines the viewing/aiming direction of the controlled Pawn and is affected by input such as from a mouse or gamepad. @see https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Gameplay/Framework/Controller/

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AController.bAttachToPawn
member.summary: If true, the controller location will match the possessed Pawn's location. If false, it will not be updated. Rotation will match ControlRotation in either case. Since a Controller's location is normally inaccessible, this is intended mainly for purposes of being able to attach an Actor that follows the possessed Pawn location, but that still has the full aim rotation (since a Pawn might update only some components of the rotation).

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.AGameMode
member.summary: The GameMode defines the game being played. It governs the game rules, scoring, what actors are allowed to exist in this game type, and who may enter the game. It is only instanced on the server and will never exist on the client. A GameMode actor is instantiated when the level is initialized for gameplay in C++ UGameEngine::LoadMap(). The class of this GameMode actor is determined by (in order) either the URL ?game=xxx, the GameMode Override value set in the World Settings, or the DefaultGameMode entry set in the game's Project Settings. @see https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Gameplay/Framework/GameMode/index.html

member.summary: MAXPOSITIONERRORSQUARED is the square of the max position error that is accepted (not corrected) in net play

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.MAXNEARZEROVELOCITYSQUARED
member.summary: MAXNEARZEROVELOCITYSQUARED is the square of the max velocity that is considered zero (not corrected) in net play

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.CLIENTADJUSTUPDATECOST
member.summary: CLIENTADJUSTUPDATECOST is the bandwidth cost in bytes of sending a client adjustment update. 180 is greater than the actual cost, but represents a tweaked value reserving enough bandwidth for other updates sent to the client. Increase this value to reduce client adjustment update frequency, or if the amount of data sent in the clientadjustment() call increases

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.MAXCLIENTUPDATEINTERVAL
member.summary: MAXCLIENTUPDATEINTERVAL is the maximum time between movement updates from the client before the server forces an update.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.MaxMoveDeltaTime
member.summary: MaxMoveDeltaTime is the default maximum time delta of CharacterMovement ServerMoves. Should be less than or equal to MAXCLIENTUPDATEINTERVAL, otherwise server will interfere by forceing position updates

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.ClientAuthorativePosition
member.summary: If client update is within MAXPOSITIONERRORSQUARED then he is authorative on his final position

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.ClientErrorUpdateRateLimit
member.summary: Minimum delay between the server sending error corrections to a client, in seconds.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.bMovementTimeDiscrepancyDetection
member.summary: Whether movement time discrepancy detection is enabled.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.bMovementTimeDiscrepancyResolution
member.summary: Whether movement time discrepancy resolution is enabled (when detected, make client movement "pay back" excessive time discrepancies)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.MovementTimeDiscrepancyMaxTimeMargin
member.summary: Maximum time client can be ahead before triggering movement time discrepancy detection/resolution (if enabled).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.MovementTimeDiscrepancyMinTimeMargin
member.summary: Maximum time client can be behind.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.MovementTimeDiscrepancyResolutionRate
member.summary: During time discrepancy resolution, we "pay back" the time discrepancy at this rate for future moves until total error is zero. 1.0 = 100% resolution rate, meaning the next X ServerMoves from the client are fully paying back the time, 0.5 = 50% resolution rate, meaning future ServerMoves will spend 50% of tick continuing to move the character and 50% paying back. Lowering from 100% could be used to produce less severe/noticeable corrections, although typically we would want to correct the client as quickly as possible.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.MovementTimeDiscrepancyDriftAllowance
member.summary: Accepted drift in clocks between client and server as a percent per second allowed. 0.0 is "no forgiveness" and all logic would run on raw values, no tampering on the server side. 0.02 would be a 2% per second difference "forgiven" - if the time discrepancy in a given second was less than 2%, the error handling/detection code effectively ignores it. Increasing this value above 0% lessens the chance of false positives on time discrepancy (burst packet loss, performance hitches), but also means anyone tampering with their client time below that percent will not be detected and no resolution action will be taken, and anyone above that threshold will still gain the advantage of this % of time boost (if running at 10% speed-up and this value is 0.05 or 5% allowance, they would only be resolved down to a 5% speed boost). Time discrepancy detection code DOES keep track of LifetimeRawTimeDiscrepancy, which is unaffected by this drift allowance, so cheating below DriftAllowance percent could be tracked and acted on outside of an individual game. For example, if DriftAllowance was 0.05 (meaning we're not going to actively prevent any cheating below 5% boosts to ensure less false positives for normal players), we could still post-process analytics of the game showing that Player X regularly runs at 4% speed boost and take action.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.bMovementTimeDiscrepancyForceCorrectionsDuringResolution
member.summary: Whether client moves should be force corrected during time discrepancy resolution, useful for projects that have lenient move error tolerance/ClientAuthorativePosition enabled.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AGameNetworkManager.bUseDistanceBasedRelevancy
member.summary: If true, actor network relevancy is constrained by whether they are within their NetCullDistanceSquared from the client's view point.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.APlayerCameraManager
member.summary: A PlayerCameraManager is responsible for managing the camera for a particular player. It defines the final view properties used by other systems (e.g. the renderer), meaning you can think of it as your virtual eyeball in the world. It can compute the final camera properties directly, or it can arbitrate/blend between other objects or actors that influence the camera (e.g. blending from one CameraActor to another). The PlayerCameraManagers primary external responsibility is to reliably respond to various Get*() functions, such as GetCameraViewPoint. Most everything else is implementation detail and overrideable by user projects. By default, a PlayerCameraManager maintains a "view target", which is the primary actor the camera is associated with. It can also apply various "post" effects to the final view state, such as camera animations, shakes, post-process effects or special effects such as dirt on the lens. @see https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Gameplay/Framework/Camera/

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.APlayerController
member.summary: PlayerControllers are used by human players to control Pawns. ControlRotation (accessed via GetControlRotation()), determines the aiming orientation of the controlled Pawn. In networked games, PlayerControllers exist on the server for every player-controlled pawn, and also on the controlling client's machine. They do NOT exist on a client's machine for pawns controlled by remote players elsewhere on the network. @see https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Gameplay/Framework/Controller/PlayerController/

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.APlayerController.GetFocalLocation
member.summary: Returns the location the PlayerController is focused on. If there is a possessed Pawn, returns the Pawn's location. If there is a spectator Pawn, returns that Pawn's location. Otherwise, returns the PlayerController's spawn location (usually the last known Pawn location after it has died).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.ARecastNavMesh.bSortNavigationAreasByCost
member.summary: Controls whether Navigation Areas will be sorted by cost before application to navmesh during navmesh generation. This is relevant then there are areas overlapping and we want to have area cost express area relevancy as well. Setting it to true will result in having area sorted by cost, but it will also increase navmesh generation cost a bit

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.ARecastNavMesh.bPerformVoxelFiltering

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.bMinimizeBSPSections
member.summary: Causes the BSP build to generate as few sections as possible. This is useful when you need to reduce draw calls but can reduce texture streaming efficiency and effective lightmap resolution. Note - changes require a rebuild to propagate. Also, be sure to select all surfaces and make sure they all have the same flags to minimize section count.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.DefaultColorScale
member.summary: Default color scale for the level

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.DefaultMaxDistanceFieldOcclusionDistance
member.summary: Max occlusion distance used by mesh distance fields, overridden if there is a movable skylight.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.GlobalDistanceFieldViewDistance
member.summary: Distance from the camera that the global distance field should cover.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.bPrecomputeVisibility
member.summary: Whether to place visibility cells inside Precomputed Visibility Volumes and along camera tracks in this level. Precomputing visibility reduces rendering thread time at the cost of some runtime memory and somewhat increased lighting build times.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.bPlaceCellsOnlyAlongCameraTracks
member.summary: Whether to place visibility cells only along camera tracks or only above shadow casting surfaces.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.VisibilityCellSize
member.summary: World space size of precomputed visibility cells in x and y. Smaller sizes produce more effective occlusion culling at the cost of increased runtime memory usage and lighting build times.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.VisibilityAggressiveness
member.summary: Determines how aggressive precomputed visibility should be. More aggressive settings cull more objects but also cause more visibility errors like popping.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.bForceNoPrecomputedLighting
member.summary: Whether to force lightmaps and other precomputed lighting to not be created even when the engine thinks they are needed. This is useful for improving iteration in levels with fully dynamic lighting and shadowing. Note that any lighting and shadowing interactions that are usually precomputed will be lost if this is enabled.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.AWorldSettings.LevelLightingQuality
member.summary: The lighting quality the level was last built with

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.EButtonClickMethod
member.summary: Enumerates different methods that a button click can be triggered. Normally, DownAndUp is appropriate.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EButtonClickMethod.DownAndUp
member.summary: User must press the button, then release while over the button to trigger the click. This is the most common type of button.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EButtonClickMethod.MouseDown
member.summary: Click will be triggered immediately on mouse down, and mouse will not be captured.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EButtonClickMethod.MouseUp
member.summary: Click will always be triggered when mouse button is released over the button, even if the button wasn't pressed down over it.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EButtonClickMethod.PreciseClick
member.summary: Inside a list, buttons can only be clicked with precise tap. Moving the pointer will scroll the list, also allows drag-droppable buttons.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.ECollisionChannel
F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionChannel.ECC_WorldStatic
member.summary: @NOTE!!!! This DisplayName [DISPLAYNAME] SHOULD MATCH suffix of ECC_DISPLAYNAME Otherwise it will mess up collision profile loading If you change this, please also change FCollisionResponseContainers If you add any more TraceQuery="1", you also should change UCollsionProfile::LoadProfileConfig Metadata doesn't work outside of editor, so you'll need to add manually

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionChannel.ECC_EngineTraceChannel1
member.summary: Unspecified Engine Trace Channels

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionChannel.ECC_EngineTraceChannel2
member.summary: IMPORTANT: This engine trace channel is reserved by the COLLISION_GIZMO definition

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionChannel.ECC_GameTraceChannel1
member.summary: in order to use this custom channels we recommend to define in your local file - i.e. #define COLLISION_WEAPON ECC_GameTraceChannel1 and make sure you customize these it in INI file by in DefaultEngine.ini [/Script/Engine.CollisionProfile] GameTraceChannel1="Weapon" also in the INI file, you can override collision profiles that are defined by simply redefining note that Weapon isn't defined in the BaseEngine.ini file, but "Trigger" is defined in Engine +Profiles=(Name="Trigger",CollisionEnabled=QueryOnly,ObjectTypeName=WorldDynamic, DefaultResponse=ECR_Overlap, CustomResponses=((Channel=Visibility, Response=ECR_Ignore), (Channel=Weapon, Response=ECR_Ignore)))

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionChannel.ECC_OverlapAll_Deprecated
member.summary: can't add displaynames because then it will show up in the collision channel option

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.ECollisionEnabled
member.summary: Enum used to describe what type of collision is enabled on a body.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionEnabled.NoCollision
member.summary: Will not create any representation in the physics engine. Cannot be used for spatial queries (raycasts, sweeps, overlaps) or simulation (rigid body, constraints). Best performance possible (especially for moving objects)

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionEnabled.QueryOnly
member.summary: Only used for spatial queries (raycasts, sweeps, and overlaps). Cannot be used for simulation (rigid body, constraints). Useful for character movement and things that do not need physical simulation. Performance gains by keeping data out of simulation tree.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionEnabled.PhysicsOnly
member.summary: Only used only for physics simulation (rigid body, constraints). Cannot be used for spatial queries (raycasts, sweeps, overlaps). Useful for jiggly bits on characters that do not need per bone detection. Performance gains by keeping data out of query tree

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionEnabled.QueryAndPhysics
member.summary: Can be used for both spatial queries (raycasts, sweeps, overlaps) and simulation (rigid body, constraints).

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.ECollisionResponse
member.summary: Enum indicating how each type should respond

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionTraceFlag.CTF_UseDefault
member.summary: Use project physics settings (DefaultShapeComplexity)

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionTraceFlag.CTF_UseSimpleAndComplex
member.summary: Create both simple and complex shapes. Simple shapes are used for regular scene queries and collision tests. Complex shape (per poly) is used for complex scene queries.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionTraceFlag.CTF_UseSimpleAsComplex
member.summary: Create only simple shapes. Use simple shapes for all scene queries and collision tests.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ECollisionTraceFlag.CTF_UseComplexAsSimple
member.summary: Create only complex shapes (per poly). Use complex shapes for all scene queries and collision tests. Can be used in simulation for static shapes only (i.e can be collided against but not moved through forces or velocity.)

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.EComponentMobility
member.summary: Describes how often this component is allowed to move.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EComponentMobility.Static
member.summary: Static objects cannot be moved or changed in game. - Allows baked lighting - Fastest rendering

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EComponentMobility.Stationary
member.summary: A stationary light will only have its shadowing and bounced lighting from static geometry baked by Lightmass, all other lighting will be dynamic. - Stationary only makes sense for light components - It can change color and intensity in game. - Can't move - Allows partial baked lighting - Dynamic shadows

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EComponentMobility.Movable
member.summary: Movable objects can be moved and changed in game. - Totally dynamic - Can cast dynamic shadows - Slowest rendering

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMaxConcurrentResolutionRule.StopFarthestThenPreventNew
member.summary: When Max Concurrent sounds are active stop the furthest sound. If all sounds are the same distance then do not start a new sound.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMaxConcurrentResolutionRule.StopFarthestThenOldest
member.summary: When Max Concurrent sounds are active stop the furthest sound. If all sounds are the same distance then stop the oldest.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMaxConcurrentResolutionRule.StopLowestPriority
member.summary: Stop the lowest priority sound in the group. If all sounds are the same priority, then it will stop the oldest sound in the group.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMaxConcurrentResolutionRule.StopQuietest
member.summary: Stop the sound that is quietest in the group.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMaxConcurrentResolutionRule.StopLowestPriorityThenPreventNew
member.summary: Stop the lowest priority sound in the group. If all sounds are the same priority, then it won't play a new sound.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMovementMode.MOVE_NavWalking
member.summary: Simplified walking on navigation data (e.g. navmesh). If bGenerateOverlapEvents is true, then we will perform sweeps with each navmesh move. If bGenerateOverlapEvents is false then movement is cheaper but characters can overlap other objects without some extra process to repel/resolve their collisions.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMovementMode.MOVE_Swimming
member.summary: Swimming through a fluid volume, under the effects of gravity and buoyancy.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMovementMode.MOVE_Flying
member.summary: Flying, ignoring the effects of gravity. Affected by the current physics volume's fluid friction.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.EMovementMode.MOVE_Custom

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.ERefractionMode
member.summary: Determines how the refraction offset should be computed for the material.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERefractionMode.RM_IndexOfRefraction
member.summary: Refraction is computed based on the camera vector entering a medium whose index of refraction is defined by the Refraction material input. The new medium's surface is defined by the material's normal. With this mode, a flat plane seen from the side will have a constant refraction offset. This is a physical model of refraction but causes reading outside the scene color texture so is a poor fit for large refractive surfaces like water.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERefractionMode.RM_PixelNormalOffset
member.summary: The refraction offset into Scene Color is computed based on the difference between the per-pixel normal and the per-vertex normal. With this mode, a material whose normal is the default (0, 0, 1) will never cause any refraction. This mode is only valid with tangent space normals. The refraction material input scales the offset, although a value of 1.0 maps to no refraction, and a value of 2 maps to a scale of 1.0 on the offset. This is a non-physical model of refraction but is useful on large refractive surfaces like water, since offsets have to stay small to avoid reading outside scene color.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERoundingMode.HalfToEven
member.summary: Rounds to the nearest place, equidistant ties go to the value which is closest to an even value: 1.5 becomes 2, 0.5 becomes 0

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERoundingMode.HalfFromZero
member.summary: Rounds to nearest place, equidistant ties go to the value which is further from zero: -0.5 becomes -1.0, 0.5 becomes 1.0

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERoundingMode.HalfToZero
member.summary: Rounds to nearest place, equidistant ties go to the value which is closer to zero: -0.5 becomes 0, 0.5 becomes 0.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERoundingMode.FromZero
member.summary: Rounds to the value which is further from zero, "larger" in absolute value: 0.1 becomes 1, -0.1 becomes -1

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERoundingMode.ToZero
member.summary: Rounds to the value which is closer to zero, "smaller" in absolute value: 0.1 becomes 0, -0.1 becomes 0

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERoundingMode.ToNegativeInfinity
member.summary: Rounds to the value which is more negative: 0.1 becomes 0, -0.1 becomes -1

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ERoundingMode.ToPositiveInfinity
member.summary: Rounds to the value which is more positive: 0.1 becomes 1, -0.1 becomes 0

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.ESubUVBoundingVertexCount
member.summary: More bounding vertices results in reduced overdraw, but adds more triangle overhead. The eight vertex mode is best used when the SubUV texture has a lot of space to cut out that is not captured by the four vertex version, and when the particles using the texture will be few and large.

member.summary: Justify the text logically to the left. When text is flowing left-to-right, this will align text visually to the left. When text is flowing right-to-left, this will align text visually to the right.

member.summary: Justify the text in the center. Text flow direction has no impact on this justification mode.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETextJustify.Right
member.summary: Justify the text logically to the right. When text is flowing left-to-right, this will align text visually to the right. When text is flowing right-to-left, this will align text visually to the left.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.ETextShapingMethod
member.summary: Methods that can be used to shape text. @note If you change this enum, make sure and update CVarDefaultTextShapingMethod and GetDefaultTextShapingMethod.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETextShapingMethod.Auto
member.summary: Automatically picks the fastest possible shaping method (either KerningOnly or FullShaping) based on the reading direction of the text. Left-to-right text uses the KerningOnly method, and right-to-left text uses the FullShaping method.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETextShapingMethod.KerningOnly
member.summary: Provides fake shaping using only kerning data. This can be faster than full shaping, but won't render complex right-to-left or bi-directional glyphs (such as Arabic) correctly. This can be useful as an optimization when you know your text block will only show simple glyphs (such as numbers).

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETextShapingMethod.FullShaping
member.summary: Provides full text shaping, allowing accurate rendering of complex right-to-left or bi-directional glyphs (such as Arabic). This mode will perform ligature replacement for all languages (such as the combined "fi" glyph in English).

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucencyLightingMode.TLM_VolumetricNonDirectional
member.summary: Lighting will be calculated for a volume, without directionality. Use this on particle effects like smoke and dust. This is the cheapest per-pixel lighting method, however the material normal is not taken into account.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucencyLightingMode.TLM_VolumetricDirectional
member.summary: Lighting will be calculated for a volume, with directionality so that the normal of the material is taken into account. Note that the default particle tangent space is facing the camera, so enable bGenerateSphericalParticleNormals to get a more useful tangent space.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucencyLightingMode.TLM_VolumetricPerVertexNonDirectional
member.summary: Same as Volumetric Non Directional, but lighting is only evaluated at vertices so the pixel shader cost is significantly less. Note that lighting still comes from a volume texture, so it is limited in range. Directional lights become unshadowed in the distance.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucencyLightingMode.TLM_VolumetricPerVertexDirectional
member.summary: Same as Volumetric Directional, but lighting is only evaluated at vertices so the pixel shader cost is significantly less. Note that lighting still comes from a volume texture, so it is limited in range. Directional lights become unshadowed in the distance.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucencyLightingMode.TLM_Surface
member.summary: Lighting will be calculated for a surface. The light in accumulated in a volume so the result is blurry, limited distance but the per pixel cost is very low. Use this on translucent surfaces like glass and water. Only diffuse lighting is supported.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucencyLightingMode.TLM_SurfacePerPixelLighting
member.summary: Lighting will be calculated for a surface. Use this on translucent surfaces like glass and water. This is implemented with forward shading so specular highlights from local lights are supported, however many deferred-only features are not. This is the most expensive translucency lighting method as each light's contribution is computed per-pixel.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.ETranslucentSortPolicy
member.summary: Enumerates available options for the translucency sort policy.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucentSortPolicy.SortByDistance
member.summary: Sort based on distance from camera centerpoint to bounding sphere centerpoint. (Default, best for 3D games.)

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucentSortPolicy.SortByProjectedZ
member.summary: Sort based on the post-projection Z distance to the camera.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.ETranslucentSortPolicy.SortAlongAxis
member.summary: Sort based on the projection onto a fixed axis. (Best for 2D games.)

member.summary: Default animation settings.

member.summary: compression upgrade version

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimationSettings.AlternativeCompressionThreshold
member.summary: The alternate error threshold (0.0 means don't try anything other than the current / default scheme) Determines the current setting for world-space error tolerance in the animation compressor. When requested, animation being compressed will also consider an alternative compression method if the end result of that method produces less error than the AlternativeCompressionThreshold. Also known as "Max End Effector Error"

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimationSettings.bForceBelowThreshold
member.summary: If true and the existing compression error is greater than Alternative Compression Threshold, then any compression technique (even one that increases the size) with a lower error will be used until it falls below the threshold

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimationSettings.bFirstRecompressUsingCurrentOrDefault
member.summary: If true, then the animation will be first recompressed with it's current compressor if non-NULL, or with the global default compressor (specified in the engine ini) Also known as "Run Current Default Compressor"

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimationSettings.bRaiseMaxErrorToExisting
member.summary: If true and the existing compression error is greater than Alternative Compression Threshold, then Alternative Compression Threshold will be effectively raised to the existing error level

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimationSettings.bTryFixedBitwiseCompression
member.summary: If true, the uniform bitwise techniques will be tried

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimationSettings.bTryPerTrackBitwiseCompression
member.summary: If true, the per-track compressor techniques will be tried

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimationSettings.bTryLinearKeyRemovalCompression
member.summary: If true, the linear key removal techniques will be tried

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimationSettings.bTryIntervalKeyRemoval

member.summary: An Anim Blueprint is essentially a specialized Blueprint whose graphs control the animation of a Skeletal Mesh. It can perform blending of animations, directly control the bones of the skeleton, and output a final pose for a Skeletal Mesh each frame.

member.summary: Name of Compression Scheme used for this asset

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress.bNeedsSkeleton
member.summary: Compression algorithms requiring a skeleton should set this value to true.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress.TranslationCompressionFormat
member.summary: Format for bitwise compression of translation data.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress.RotationCompressionFormat
member.summary: Format for bitwise compression of rotation data.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress.ScaleCompressionFormat
member.summary: Format for bitwise compression of scale data.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_Automatic.MaxEndEffectorError
member.summary: Maximum amount of error that a compression technique can introduce in an end effector Determines the current setting for world - space error tolerance in the animation compressor. When requested, animation being compressed will also consider an alternative compression method if the end result of that method produces less error than the AlternativeCompressionThreshold. Also known as "Alternative Compression Threshold"

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_Automatic.bTryFixedBitwiseCompression
member.summary: If true, the uniform bitwise techniques will be tried

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_Automatic.bTryPerTrackBitwiseCompression
member.summary: If true, the per-track compressor techniques will be tried

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_Automatic.bTryLinearKeyRemovalCompression
member.summary: If true, the linear key removal techniques will be tried

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_Automatic.bTryIntervalKeyRemoval
member.summary: If true, the resampling techniques will be tried

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_Automatic.bRunCurrentDefaultCompressor
member.summary: If true, then the animation will be first recompressed with it's current compressor if non-NULL, or with the global default compressor (specified in the engine ini) Also known as "First Recompress Using Current Or Default"

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_Automatic.bAutoReplaceIfExistingErrorTooGreat
member.summary: If true and the existing compression error is greater than Max End Effector Error, then any compression technique (even one that increases the size) with a lower error will be used until it falls below the threshold Also known as "force below threshold"

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_Automatic.bRaiseMaxErrorToExisting
member.summary: If true and the existing compression error is greater than Max End Effector Error, then Max End Effector Error will be effectively raised to the existing error level

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveEverySecondKey.MinKeys
member.summary: Animations with fewer than MinKeys will not lose any keys.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveEverySecondKey.bStartAtSecondKey
member.summary: If bStartAtSecondKey is true, remove keys 1,3,5,etc. If bStartAtSecondKey is false, remove keys 0,2,4,etc.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.MaxPosDiff
member.summary: Maximum position difference to use when testing if an animation key may be removed. Lower values retain more keys, but yield less compression.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.MaxAngleDiff
member.summary: Maximum angle difference to use when testing if an animation key may be removed. Lower values retain more keys, but yield less compression.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.MaxScaleDiff
member.summary: Maximum Scale difference to use when testing if an animation key may be removed. Lower values retain more keys, but yield less compression.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.MaxEffectorDiff
member.summary: As keys are tested for removal, we monitor the effects all the way down to the end effectors. If their position changes by more than this amount as a result of removing a key, the key will be retained. This value is used for all bones except the end-effectors parent.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.MinEffectorDiff
member.summary: As keys are tested for removal, we monitor the effects all the way down to the end effectors. If their position changes by more than this amount as a result of removing a key, the key will be retained. This value is used for the end-effectors parent, allowing tighter restrictions near the end of a skeletal chain.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.EffectorDiffSocket
member.summary: Error threshold for End Effectors with Sockets attached to them. Typically more important bone, where we want to be less aggressive with compression.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.ParentKeyScale
member.summary: A scale value which increases the likelihood that a bone will retain a key if it's parent also had a key at the same time position. Higher values can remove shaking artifacts from the animation, at the cost of compression.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.bRetarget
member.summary: true = As the animation is compressed, adjust animated nodes to compensate for compression error. false= Do not adjust animated nodes.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimCompress_RemoveLinearKeys.bActuallyFilterLinearKeys
member.summary: Controls whether the final filtering step will occur, or only the retargetting after bitwise compression. If both this and bRetarget are false, then the linear compressor will do no better than the underlying bitwise compressor, extremely slowly.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UAnimInstance.Montage_SetNextSection(System.String,System.String,UnrealEngine.UAnimMontage)
member.summary: Relink new next section AFTER SectionNameToChange in run-time You can link section order the way you like in editor, but in run-time if you'd like to change it dynamically, use this function to relink the next section For example, you can have Start->Loop->Loop->Loop.... but when you want it to end, you can relink next section of Loop to be End to finish the montage, in which case, it stops looping by Loop->End. @param SectionNameToChange : This should be the name of the Montage Section after which you want to insert a new next section @param NextSection : new next section

Only native update is permitted.

member.summary: The following arrays are used to handle property changes during a state. Because we can't store any stateful data here we can't know which emitter is ours. The best metric we have is an emitter on our Mesh Component with the same template and socket name we have defined. Because these can change at any time we need to track previous versions when we are in an editor build. Refactor when stateful data is possible, tracking our component instead.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAnimNotifyState_Trail.WidthScaleMode
member.summary: Controls the way width scale is applied. In each method a width scale of 1.0 will mean the width is unchanged from the position of the sockets. A width scale of 0.0 will cause a trail of zero width. From Centre = Trail width is scaled outwards from the centre point between the two sockets. From First = Trail width is scaled outwards from the position of the first socket. From Second = Trail width is scaled outwards from the position of the Second socket.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.UApplicationLifecycleComponent
member.summary: Component to handle receiving notifications from the OS about application state (activated, suspended, termination, etc).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UApplicationLifecycleComponent.ApplicationWillDeactivateDelegate
member.summary: This is called when the application is about to be deactivated (e.g., due to a phone call or SMS or the sleep button). The game should be paused if possible, etc...

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UApplicationLifecycleComponent.ApplicationHasReactivatedDelegate
member.summary: Called when the application has been reactivated (reverse any processing done in the Deactivate delegate)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UApplicationLifecycleComponent.ApplicationWillEnterBackgroundDelegate
member.summary: This is called when the application is being backgrounded (e.g., due to switching to another app or closing it via the home button) The game should release shared resources, save state, etc..., since it can be terminated from the background state without any further warning.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UApplicationLifecycleComponent.ApplicationHasEnteredForegroundDelegate
member.summary: Called when the application is returning to the foreground (reverse any processing done in the EnterBackground delegate)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UApplicationLifecycleComponent.ApplicationWillTerminateDelegate
member.summary: This *may* be called when the application is getting terminated by the OS. There is no guarantee that this will ever be called on a mobile device, save state when ApplicationWillEnterBackgroundDelegate is called instead.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UAudioSettings.DialogueFilenameFormat
member.summary: The format string to use when generating the filename for contexts within dialogue waves. This must generate unique names for your project. Available format markers: * {DialogueGuid} - The GUID of the dialogue wave. Guaranteed to be unique and stable against asset renames. * {DialogueHash} - The hash of the dialogue wave. Not guaranteed to be unique or stable against asset renames, however may be unique enough if combined with the dialogue name. * {DialogueName} - The name of the dialogue wave. Not guaranteed to be unique or stable against asset renames, however may be unique enough if combined with the dialogue hash. * {ContextId} - The ID of the context. Guaranteed to be unique within its dialogue wave. Not guaranteed to be stable against changes to the context. * {ContextIndex} - The index of the context within its parent dialogue wave. Guaranteed to be unique within its dialogue wave. Not guaranteed to be stable against contexts being removed.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UBlueprint.bDuplicatingReadOnly
member.summary: Flag indicating that a read only duplicate of this blueprint is being created, used to disable logic in ::PostDuplicate, This flag needs to be copied on duplication (because it's the duplicated object that we're disabling on PostDuplicate), but we don't *need* to serialize it for permanent objects. Without setting this flag a blueprint will be marked dirty when it is duplicated and if saved while in this dirty state you will not be able to open the blueprint. More specifically, UClass::Rename (called by DestroyGeneratedClass) sets a dirty flag on the package. Once saved the package will fail to open because some unnamed objects are present in the pacakge. This flag can be used to avoid the package being marked as dirty in the first place. Ideally PostDuplicateObject would not rename classes that are still in use by the original object.

member.summary: Used in the PhysicsAsset case. Associates this Body with Bone in a skeletal mesh.

member.summary: If Unfixed it will use physics. If fixed, it will use kinematic. Default will inherit from OwnerComponent's behavior.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UBodySetup.bAlwaysFullAnimWeight
member.summary: If true (and bEnableFullAnimWeightBodies in SkelMeshComp is true), the physics of this bone will always be blended into the skeletal mesh, regardless of what PhysicsWeight of the SkelMeshComp is. This is useful for bones that should always be physics, even when blending physics in and out for hit reactions (eg cloth or pony-tails).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UBodySetup.bConsiderForBounds
member.summary: Should this BodySetup be considered for the bounding box of the PhysicsAsset (and hence SkeletalMeshComponent). There is a speed improvement from having less BodySetups processed each frame when updating the bounds.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UBodySetup.bMeshCollideAll
member.summary: If true, the physics of this mesh (only affects static meshes) will always contain ALL elements from the mesh - not just the ones enabled for collision. This is useful for forcing high detail collisions using the entire render mesh.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UBodySetup.bDoubleSidedGeometry
member.summary: If true, the physics triangle mesh will use double sided faces when doing scene queries. This is useful for planes and single sided meshes that need traces to work on both sides.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UBodySetup.bGenerateNonMirroredCollision
member.summary: Should we generate data necessary to support collision on normal (non-mirrored) versions of this body.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UBodySetup.bSharedCookedData
member.summary: Whether the cooked data is shared by multiple body setups. This is needed for per poly collision case where we don't want to duplicate cooked data, but still need multiple body setups for in place geometry changes

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UBodySetup.bGenerateMirroredCollision
member.summary: Should we generate data necessary to support collision on mirrored versions of this mesh. This halves the collision data size for this mesh, but disables collision on mirrored instances of the body.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.UBrushBuilder
member.summary: Base class of UnrealEd brush builders. Tips for writing brush builders: - Always validate the user-specified and call BadParameters function if anything is wrong, instead of actually building geometry. If you build an invalid brush due to bad user parameters, you'll cause an extraordinary amount of pain for the poor user. - When generating polygons with more than 3 vertices, BE SURE all the polygon's vertices are coplanar! Out-of-plane polygons will cause geometry to be corrupted.

member.summary: Scaling factor applied to all camera shakes in when in splitscreen mode. Normally used to reduce shaking, since shakes feel more intense in a smaller viewport.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake
member.summary: A CameraShake is an asset that defines how to shake the camera in a particular way. CameraShakes can be authored as either oscillating shakes, animated shakes, or both. An oscillating shake will sinusoidally vibrate various camera parameters over time. Each location and rotation axis can be oscillated independently with different parameters to create complex and random-feeling shakes. These are easier to author and tweak, but can still feel mechanical and are limited to vibration-style shakes, such as earthquakes. Animated shakes play keyframed camera animations. These can take more effort to author, but enable more natural-feeling results and things like directional shakes. For instance, you can have an explosion to the camera's right push it primarily to the left.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake.bSingleInstance
member.summary: If true to only allow a single instance of this shake class to play at any given time. Subsequent attempts to play this shake will simply restart the timer.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake.OscillationDuration
member.summary: Duration in seconds of current screen shake. Less than 0 means indefinite, 0 means no oscillation.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake.OscillationBlendInTime
member.summary: Duration of the blend-in, where the oscillation scales from 0 to 1.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake.OscillationBlendOutTime
member.summary: Duration of the blend-out, where the oscillation scales from 1 to 0.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake.RotOscillation
member.summary: Rotational oscillation

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake.LocOscillation
member.summary: Positional oscillation

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake.AnimBlendInTime
member.summary: Linear blend-in time.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCameraShake.AnimBlendOutTime

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.UCanvasRenderTarget2D
member.summary: CanvasRenderTarget2D is 2D render target which exposes a Canvas interface to allow you to draw elements onto it directly. Use FindCanvasRenderTarget2D() to find or create a render target texture by unique name, then bind a function to the OnCanvasRenderTargetUpdate delegate which will be called when the render target is updated. If you need to repaint your canvas every single frame, simply call UpdateResource() on it from a Tick function. Also, remember to hold onto your new canvas render target with a reference so that it doesn't get garbage collected.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UCanvasRenderTarget2D.GetSize(System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
M:UnrealEngine.UCanvasRenderTarget2D.CreateCanvasRenderTarget2D(UnrealEngine.UObject,UnrealEngine.TSubclassOf{UnrealEngine.UCanvasRenderTarget2D},System.Int32,System.Int32)
M:UnrealEngine.UCanvasRenderTarget2D.UpdateResource
member.summary: Updates the the canvas render target texture's resource. This is where the render target will create or find a canvas object to use. It also calls UpdateResourceImmediate() to clear the render target texture from the deferred rendering list, to stop the texture from being cleared the next frame. From there it will ask the rendering thread to set up the RHI viewport. The canvas is then set up for rendering and then the user's update delegate is called. The canvas is then flushed and the RHI resolves the texture to make it available for rendering.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCanvasRenderTarget2D.OnCanvasRenderTargetUpdate
member.summary: Called when this Canvas Render Target is asked to update its texture resource.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCanvasRenderTarget2D.bShouldClearRenderTargetOnReceiveUpdate
member.summary: If true, clear the render target to green whenever OnReceiveUpdate() is called. (Defaults to true.) If false, the render target will retain whatever values it had, allowing the user to update only areas that have changed.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent
member.summary: CharacterMovementComponent handles movement logic for the associated Character owner. It supports various movement modes including: walking, falling, swimming, flying, custom. Movement is affected primarily by current Velocity and Acceleration. Acceleration is updated each frame based on the input vector accumulated thus far (see UPawnMovementComponent::GetPendingInputVector()). Networking is fully implemented, with server-client correction and prediction included. @see ACharacter, UPawnMovementComponent @see https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Gameplay/Framework/Pawn/Character/
Replicate root motion source correction to client when using root motion for movement.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.AddForce(UnrealEngine.FVector)
member.summary: Add force to character. Forces are accumulated each tick and applied together so multiple calls to this function will accumulate. Forces are scaled depending on timestep, so they can be applied each frame. If you want an instantaneous force, use AddImpulse. Adding a force always takes the actor's mass into account. Note that changing the momentum of characters like this can change the movement mode. @param Force Force to apply.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.AddImpulse(UnrealEngine.FVector,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Add impulse to character. Impulses are accumulated each tick and applied together so multiple calls to this function will accumulate. An impulse is an instantaneous force, usually applied once. If you want to continually apply forces each frame, use AddForce(). Note that changing the momentum of characters like this can change the movement mode. @param Impulse Impulse to apply. @param bVelocityChange Whether or not the impulse is relative to mass.

member.summary: Fraction of JumpZVelocity to use when automatically "jumping off" of a base actor that's not allowed to be a base for a character. (For example, if you're not allowed to stand on other players.)

member.summary: Max angle in degrees of a walkable surface. Any greater than this and it is too steep to be walkable.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.WalkableFloorZ
member.summary: Minimum Z value for floor normal. If less, not a walkable surface. Computed from WalkableFloorAngle.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MovementMode
member.summary: Actor's current movement mode (walking, falling, etc). - walking: Walking on a surface, under the effects of friction, and able to "step up" barriers. Vertical velocity is zero. - falling: Falling under the effects of gravity, after jumping or walking off the edge of a surface. - flying: Flying, ignoring the effects of gravity. - swimming: Swimming through a fluid volume, under the effects of gravity and buoyancy. - custom: User-defined custom movement mode, including many possible sub-modes. This is automatically replicated through the Character owner and for client-server movement functions. @see SetMovementMode(), CustomMovementMode

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.CustomMovementMode
P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.GroundFriction
member.summary: Setting that affects movement control. Higher values allow faster changes in direction. If bUseSeparateBrakingFriction is false, also affects the ability to stop more quickly when braking (whenever Acceleration is zero), where it is multiplied by BrakingFrictionFactor. When braking, this property allows you to control how much friction is applied when moving across the ground, applying an opposing force that scales with current velocity. This can be used to simulate slippery surfaces such as ice or oil by changing the value (possibly based on the material pawn is standing on). @see BrakingDecelerationWalking, BrakingFriction, bUseSeparateBrakingFriction, BrakingFrictionFactor

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxWalkSpeed
member.summary: The maximum ground speed when walking. Also determines maximum lateral speed when falling.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxWalkSpeedCrouched
member.summary: The maximum ground speed when walking and crouched.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxSwimSpeed
member.summary: The maximum swimming speed.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxFlySpeed
member.summary: The maximum flying speed.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxCustomMovementSpeed
member.summary: The maximum speed when using Custom movement mode.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxAcceleration
member.summary: Max Acceleration (rate of change of velocity)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.BrakingFrictionFactor
P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.BrakingFriction
P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bUseSeparateBrakingFriction
member.summary: If true, BrakingFriction will be used to slow the character to a stop (when there is no Acceleration). If false, braking uses the same friction passed to CalcVelocity() (ie GroundFriction when walking), multiplied by BrakingFrictionFactor. This setting applies to all movement modes; if only desired in certain modes, consider toggling it when movement modes change. @see BrakingFriction

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.BrakingDecelerationWalking
member.summary: Deceleration when walking and not applying acceleration. This is a constant opposing force that directly lowers velocity by a constant value. @see GroundFriction, MaxAcceleration

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.BrakingDecelerationFalling
member.summary: Lateral deceleration when falling and not applying acceleration. @see MaxAcceleration

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.BrakingDecelerationSwimming
member.summary: Deceleration when swimming and not applying acceleration. @see MaxAcceleration

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.BrakingDecelerationFlying
member.summary: Deceleration when flying and not applying acceleration. @see MaxAcceleration

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.AirControl
member.summary: When falling, amount of lateral movement control available to the character. 0 = no control, 1 = full control at max speed of MaxWalkSpeed.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.AirControlBoostMultiplier
member.summary: When falling, multiplier applied to AirControl when lateral velocity is less than AirControlBoostVelocityThreshold. Setting this to zero will disable air control boosting. Final result is clamped at 1.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.AirControlBoostVelocityThreshold
member.summary: When falling, if lateral velocity magnitude is less than this value, AirControl is multiplied by AirControlBoostMultiplier. Setting this to zero will disable air control boosting.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.FallingLateralFriction
P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.CrouchedHalfHeight
member.summary: Collision half-height when crouching (component scale is applied separately)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.Buoyancy
member.summary: Water buoyancy. A ratio (1.0 = neutral buoyancy, 0.0 = no buoyancy)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.PerchRadiusThreshold
member.summary: Don't allow the character to perch on the edge of a surface if the contact is this close to the edge of the capsule. Note that characters will not fall off if they are within MaxStepHeight of a walkable surface below.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.PerchAdditionalHeight
member.summary: When perching on a ledge, add this additional distance to MaxStepHeight when determining how high above a walkable floor we can perch. Note that we still enforce MaxStepHeight to start the step up; this just allows the character to hang off the edge or step slightly higher off the floor. (@see PerchRadiusThreshold)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.RotationRate
member.summary: Change in rotation per second, used when UseControllerDesiredRotation or OrientRotationToMovement are true. Set a negative value for infinite rotation rate and instant turns.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bUseControllerDesiredRotation
member.summary: If true, smoothly rotate the Character toward the Controller's desired rotation, using RotationRate as the rate of rotation change. Overridden by OrientRotationToMovement.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bOrientRotationToMovement
member.summary: If true, rotate the Character toward the direction of acceleration, using RotationRate as the rate of rotation change. Overrides UseControllerDesiredRotation. Normally you will want to make sure that other settings are cleared, such as bUseControllerRotationYaw on the Character.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bMovementInProgress
P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bEnableScopedMovementUpdates
P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bForceMaxAccel
member.summary: Ignores size of acceleration component, and forces max acceleration to drive character at full velocity.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bRunPhysicsWithNoController
member.summary: If true, movement will be performed even if there is no Controller for the Character owner. Normally without a Controller, movement will be aborted and velocity and acceleration are zeroed if the character is walking. Characters that are spawned without a Controller but with this flag enabled will initialize the movement mode to DefaultLandMovementMode or DefaultWaterMovementMode appropriately. @see DefaultLandMovementMode, DefaultWaterMovementMode

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bForceNextFloorCheck
member.summary: Force the Character in MOVE_Walking to do a check for a valid floor even if he hasn't moved. Cleared after next floor check. Normally if bAlwaysCheckFloor is false we try to avoid the floor check unless some conditions are met, but this can be used to force the next check to always run.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bShrinkProxyCapsule
member.summary: If true, the capsule needs to be shrunk on this simulated proxy, to avoid replication rounding putting us in geometry. Whenever this is set to true, this will cause the capsule to be shrunk again on the next update, and then set to false.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bCanWalkOffLedges
member.summary: If true, Character can walk off a ledge.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bCanWalkOffLedgesWhenCrouching
member.summary: If true, Character can walk off a ledge when crouching.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bDeferUpdateMoveComponent
member.summary: true to update CharacterOwner and UpdatedComponent after movement ends

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.DeferredUpdatedMoveComponent
member.summary: What to update CharacterOwner and UpdatedComponent after movement ends

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxOutOfWaterStepHeight
member.summary: Maximum step height for getting out of water

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.OutofWaterZ
member.summary: Z velocity applied when pawn tries to get out of water

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.Mass
member.summary: Mass of pawn (for when momentum is imparted to it).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bEnablePhysicsInteraction
member.summary: If enabled, the player will interact with physics objects when walking into them.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bTouchForceScaledToMass
member.summary: If enabled, the TouchForceFactor is applied per kg mass of the affected object.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bPushForceScaledToMass
member.summary: If enabled, the PushForceFactor is applied per kg mass of the affected object.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bPushForceUsingZOffset
member.summary: If enabled, the PushForce location is moved using PushForcePointZOffsetFactor. Otherwise simply use the impact point.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bScalePushForceToVelocity
member.summary: If enabled, the applied push force will try to get the physics object to the same velocity than the player, not faster. This will only scale the force down, it will never apply more force than defined by PushForceFactor.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.StandingDownwardForceScale
member.summary: Force applied to objects we stand on (due to Mass and Gravity) is scaled by this amount.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.InitialPushForceFactor
member.summary: Initial impulse force to apply when the player bounces into a blocking physics object.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.PushForceFactor
member.summary: Force to apply when the player collides with a blocking physics object.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.PushForcePointZOffsetFactor
member.summary: Z-Offset for the position the force is applied to. 0.0f is the center of the physics object, 1.0f is the top and -1.0f is the bottom of the object.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.TouchForceFactor
member.summary: Force to apply to physics objects that are touched by the player.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.RepulsionForce
member.summary: Force per kg applied constantly to all overlapping components.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bForceBraking
member.summary: Deprecated properties

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.CrouchedSpeedMultiplier
member.summary: Multiplier to max ground speed to use when crouched

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.Acceleration
member.summary: Current acceleration vector (with magnitude). This is calculated each update based on the input vector and the constraints of MaxAcceleration and the current movement mode.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.LastUpdateLocation
member.summary: Location after last PerformMovement or SimulateMovement update. Used internally to detect changes in position from outside character movement to try to validate the current floor.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.LastUpdateRotation
member.summary: Rotation after last PerformMovement or SimulateMovement update.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.LastUpdateVelocity
member.summary: Velocity after last PerformMovement or SimulateMovement update. Used internally to detect changes in velocity from external sources.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.ServerLastTransformUpdateTimeStamp
member.summary: Timestamp when location or rotation last changed during an update. Only valid on the server.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.PendingImpulseToApply
member.summary: Accumulated impulse to be added next tick.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.PendingForceToApply
member.summary: Accumulated force to be added next tick.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.AnalogInputModifier
member.summary: Modifier to applied to values such as acceleration and max speed due to analog input.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxSimulationTimeStep
member.summary: Max time delta for each discrete simulation step. Used primarily in the the more advanced movement modes that break up larger time steps (usually those applying gravity such as falling and walking). Lowering this value can address issues with fast-moving objects or complex collision scenarios, at the cost of performance. WARNING: if (MaxSimulationTimeStep * MaxSimulationIterations) is too low for the min framerate, the last simulation step may exceed MaxSimulationTimeStep to complete the simulation. @see MaxSimulationIterations

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MaxSimulationIterations
member.summary: Max number of iterations used for each discrete simulation step. Used primarily in the the more advanced movement modes that break up larger time steps (usually those applying gravity such as falling and walking). Increasing this value can address issues with fast-moving objects or complex collision scenarios, at the cost of performance. WARNING: if (MaxSimulationTimeStep * MaxSimulationIterations) is too low for the min framerate, the last simulation step may exceed MaxSimulationTimeStep to complete the simulation. @see MaxSimulationTimeStep

member.summary: If true, walking movement always maintains horizontal velocity when moving up ramps, which causes movement up ramps to be faster parallel to the ramp surface. If false, then walking movement maintains velocity magnitude parallel to the ramp surface.

member.summary: If true, impart the base actor's X velocity when falling off it (which includes jumping)

member.summary: If true, impart the base actor's Y velocity when falling off it (which includes jumping)

P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bJustTeleported
member.summary: Used by movement code to determine if a change in position is based on normal movement or a teleport. If not a teleport, velocity can be recomputed based on the change in position.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bNetworkUpdateReceived
member.summary: True when a network replication update is received for simulated proxies.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bNetworkMovementModeChanged
member.summary: True when the networked movement mode has been replicated.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bIgnoreClientMovementErrorChecksAndCorrection
member.summary: True when we should ignore server location difference checks for client error on this movement component This can be useful when character is moving at extreme speeds for a duration and you need it to look smooth on clients. Make sure to disable when done, as this would break this character's server-client movement correction.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bNotifyApex
member.summary: If true, event NotifyJumpApex() to CharacterOwner's controller when at apex of jump. Is cleared when event is triggered. By default this is off, and if you want the event to fire you typically set it to true when movement mode changes to "Falling" from another mode (see OnMovementModeChanged).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bCheatFlying
member.summary: Instantly stop when in flying mode and no acceleration is being applied.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bWantsToCrouch
member.summary: If true, try to crouch (or keep crouching) on next update. If false, try to stop crouching on next update.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bCrouchMaintainsBaseLocation
member.summary: If true, crouching should keep the base of the capsule in place by lowering the center of the shrunken capsule. If false, the base of the capsule moves up and the center stays in place. The same behavior applies when the character uncrouches: if true, the base is kept in the same location and the center moves up. If false, the capsule grows and only moves up if the base impacts something. By default this variable is set when the movement mode changes: set to true when walking and false otherwise. Feel free to override the behavior when the movement mode changes.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bIgnoreBaseRotation
member.summary: Whether the character ignores changes in rotation of the base it is standing on. If true, the character maintains current world rotation. If false, the character rotates with the moving base.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bFastAttachedMove
member.summary: Set this to true if riding on a moving base that you know is clear from non-moving world obstructions. Optimization to avoid sweeps during based movement, use with care.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bAlwaysCheckFloor
member.summary: Whether we always force floor checks for stationary Characters while walking. Normally floor checks are avoided if possible when not moving, but this can be used to force them if there are use-cases where they are being skipped erroneously (such as objects moving up into the character from below).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bUseFlatBaseForFloorChecks
member.summary: Performs floor checks as if the character is using a shape with a flat base. This avoids the situation where characters slowly lower off the side of a ledge (as their capsule 'balances' on the edge).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bPerformingJumpOff
member.summary: Used to prevent reentry of JumpOff()

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bWantsToLeaveNavWalking
member.summary: Used to safely leave NavWalking movement mode

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bUseRVOAvoidance
member.summary: If set, component will use RVO avoidance. This only runs on the server.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.bRequestedMoveUseAcceleration
member.summary: Should use acceleration for path following? If true, acceleration is applied when path following to reach the target velocity. If false, path following velocity is set directly, disregarding acceleration.

member.summary: How often we should raycast to project from navmesh to underlying geometry

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.NavMeshProjectionInterpSpeed
member.summary: Speed at which to interpolate agent navmesh offset between traces. 0: Instant (no interp) > 0: Interp speed")

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.NavMeshProjectionHeightScaleUp
member.summary: Scale of the total capsule height to use for projection from navmesh to underlying geometry in the upward direction. In other words, start the trace at [CapsuleHeight * NavMeshProjectionHeightScaleUp] above nav mesh.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.NavMeshProjectionHeightScaleDown
member.summary: Scale of the total capsule height to use for projection from navmesh to underlying geometry in the downward direction. In other words, trace down to [CapsuleHeight * NavMeshProjectionHeightScaleDown] below nav mesh.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.PostPhysicsTickFunction
member.summary: Post-physics tick function for this character

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.MinTimeBetweenTimeStampResets
member.summary: Minimum time between client TimeStamp resets. !! This has to be large enough so that we don't confuse the server if the client can stall or timeout. We do this as we use floats for TimeStamps, and server derives DeltaTime from two TimeStamps. As time goes on, accuracy decreases from those floating point numbers. So we trigger a TimeStamp reset at regular intervals to maintain a high level of accuracy.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.CurrentRootMotion
member.summary: Root Motion Group containing active root motion sources being applied to movement

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UCharacterMovementComponent.RootMotionParams

member.summary: True when SimulatedProxies are simulating RootMotion

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.UDamageType
member.summary: A DamageType is intended to define and describe a particular form of damage and to provide an avenue for customizing responses to damage from various sources. For example, a game could make a DamageType_Fire set it up to ignite the damaged actor. DamageTypes are never instanced and should be treated as immutable data holders with static code functionality. They should never be stateful.

member.summary: True if this damagetype is caused by the world (falling off level, into lava, etc).

member.summary: True to scale imparted momentum by the receiving pawn's mass for pawns using character movement

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UDamageType.DamageImpulse
member.summary: The magnitude of impulse to apply to the Actors damaged by this type.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UDamageType.bRadialDamageVelChange

member.summary: How much the damage spreads on a destructible mesh

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UDamageType.DamageFalloff
member.summary: Damage fall-off for radius damage (exponent). Default 1.0=linear, 2.0=square of distance, etc.
