member.name: T:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh
member.summary: SkeletalMesh is geometry bound to a hierarchical skeleton of bones which can be animated for the purpose of deforming the mesh. Skeletal Meshes are built up of two parts; a set of polygons composed to make up the surface of the mesh, and a hierarchical skeleton which can be used to animate the polygons. The 3D models, rigging, and animations are created in an external modeling and animation application (3DSMax, Maya, Softimage, etc). @see https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Engine/Content/Types/SkeletalMeshes/

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh.IsSectionUsingCloth(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh.GetSocketByIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a socket by index. Max index is NumSockets(). The meshes sockets are accessed first, then the skeletons.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh.NumSockets
member.summary: Returns the number of sockets available. Both on this mesh and it's skeleton.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh.FindSocketAndIndex(System.String,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Find a socket object in this SkeletalMesh by name. Entering NAME_None will return NULL. If there are multiple sockets with the same name, will return the first one. Also returns the index for the socket allowing for future fast access via GetSocketByIndex()

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh.FindSocket(System.String)
member.summary: Find a socket object in this SkeletalMesh by name. Entering NAME_None will return NULL. If there are multiple sockets with the same name, will return the first one.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh.NegativeBoundsExtension

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh.PhysicsAsset
member.summary: Physics and collision information used for this USkeletalMesh, set up in PhAT. This is used for per-bone hit detection, accurate bounding box calculation and ragdoll physics for example.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMesh.ShadowPhysicsAsset
member.summary: Physics asset whose shapes will be used for shadowing when components have bCastCharacterCapsuleDirectShadow or bCastCharacterCapsuleIndirectShadow enabled. Only spheres and sphyl shapes in the physics asset can be supported. The more shapes used, the higher the cost of the capsule shadows will be.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.SetPhysicsBlendWeight(System.Single)
member.summary: This is global set up for setting physics blend weight This does multiple things automatically If PhysicsBlendWeight == 1.f, it will enable Simulation, and if PhysicsBlendWeight == 0.f, it will disable Simulation. Also it will respect each body's setup, so if the body is fixed, it won't simulate. Vice versa So if you'd like all bodies to change manually, do not use this function, but SetAllBodiesPhysicsBlendWeight

M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.UnbindClothFromMasterPoseComponent(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If this component has a valid MasterPoseComponent and has previously had its cloth bound to the MCP, this function will unbind the cloth and resume simulation. @param bRestoreSimulationSpace if true and the master pose cloth was originally simulating in world space, we will restore this setting. This will cause the master component to reset which may be undesirable.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.BindClothToMasterPoseComponent
member.summary: If this component has a valid MasterPoseComponent then this function makes cloth items on the slave component take the transforms of the cloth items on the master component instead of simulating separately. @Note This will FORCE any cloth actor on the master component to simulate in local space. Also The meshes used in the components must be identical for the cloth to bind correctly

member.summary: Used to indicate we should force 'teleport and reset' during the next call to UpdateClothState. This can be used to reset it from a bad state or by a teleport where the old state is not important anymore.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.ForceClothNextUpdateTeleport
member.summary: Used to indicate we should force 'teleport' during the next call to UpdateClothState, This will transform positions and velocities and thus keep the simulation state, just translate it to a new pose.

member.summary: can't collide with part of environment if total collision volumes exceed 16 capsules or 32 planes per convex

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.bCollideWithAttachedChildren
member.summary: can't collide with part of attached children if total collision volumes exceed 16 capsules or 32 planes per convex

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.bLocalSpaceSimulation
member.summary: It's worth trying this option when you feel that the current cloth simulation is unstable. The scale of the actor is maintained during the simulation. It is possible to add the inertia effects to the simulation, through the inertiaScale parameter of the clothing material. So with an inertiaScale of 1.0 there should be no visible difference between local space and global space simulation. Known issues: - Currently there's simulation issues when this feature is used in 3.x (DE4076) So if localSpaceSim is enabled there's no inertia effect when the global pose of the clothing actor changes.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.bClothMorphTarget
member.summary: cloth morph target option This option will be applied only before playing because should do pre-calculation to reduce computation time for run-time play so it's impossible to change this option in run-time

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.bResetAfterTeleport
member.summary: reset the clothing after moving the clothing position (called teleport)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.TeleportDistanceThreshold
member.summary: conduct teleportation if the character's movement is greater than this threshold in 1 frame. Zero or negative values will skip the check you can also do force teleport manually using ForceNextUpdateTeleport() / ForceNextUpdateTeleportAndReset()

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.TeleportRotationThreshold
member.summary: rotation threshold in degree, ranging from 0 to 180 conduct teleportation if the character's rotation is greater than this threshold in 1 frame. Zero or negative values will skip the check

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkeletalMeshComponent.ClothBlendWeight
member.summary: weight to blend between simulated results and key-framed positions if weight is 1.0, shows only cloth simulation results and 0.0 will show only skinned results

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkinnedMeshComponent.bUseBoundsFromMasterPoseComponent
member.summary: When true, we will just using the bounds from our MasterPoseComponent. This is useful for when we have a Mesh Parented to the main SkelMesh (e.g. outline mesh or a full body overdraw effect that is toggled) that is always going to be the same bounds as parent. We want to do no calculations in that case.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkinnedMeshComponent.bCastCapsuleDirectShadow
member.summary: Whether to use the capsule representation (when present) from a skeletal mesh's ShadowPhysicsAsset for direct shadowing from lights. This type of shadowing is approximate but handles extremely wide area shadowing well. The softness of the shadow depends on the light's LightSourceAngle / SourceRadius. This flag will force bCastInsetShadow to be enabled.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkinnedMeshComponent.bCastCapsuleIndirectShadow
member.summary: Whether to use the capsule representation (when present) from a skeletal mesh's ShadowPhysicsAsset for shadowing indirect lighting (from lightmaps or skylight).

member.summary: LocalBounds cached, so they're computed just once.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkinnedMeshComponent.bCachedLocalBoundsUpToDate
member.summary: true when CachedLocalBounds is up to date.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkinnedMeshComponent.bEnableUpdateRateOptimizations
member.summary: if TRUE, Owner will determine how often animation will be updated and evaluated. See AnimUpdateRateTick() This allows to skip frames for performance. (For example based on visibility and size on screen).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkinnedMeshComponent.bDisplayDebugUpdateRateOptimizations
M:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.RecaptureSky
member.summary: Recaptures the scene for the skylight. This is useful for making sure the sky light is up to date after changing something in the world that it would capture. Warning: this is very costly and will definitely cause a hitch.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.SetCubemapBlend(UnrealEngine.UTextureCube,UnrealEngine.UTextureCube,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates sky lighting from a blend between two cubemaps, which is only valid when SourceType is set to SpecifiedCubemap. This can be used to seamlessly transition sky lighting between different times of day. The caller should continue to update the blend until BlendFraction is 0 or 1 to reduce rendering cost. The caller is responsible for avoiding pops due to changing the source or destination.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.SetCubemap(UnrealEngine.UTextureCube)
member.summary: Sets the cubemap used when SourceType is set to SpecifiedCubemap, and causes a skylight update on the next tick.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.SetLightColor(UnrealEngine.FLinearColor)
member.summary: Set color of the light

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.SourceType
member.summary: Indicates where to get the light contribution from.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.Cubemap
member.summary: Cubemap to use for sky lighting if SourceType is set to SLS_SpecifiedCubemap.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.SourceCubemapAngle
member.summary: Angle to rotate the source cubemap when SourceType is set to SLS_SpecifiedCubemap.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.CubemapResolution
member.summary: Maximum resolution for the very top processed cubemap mip. Must be a power of 2.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.SkyDistanceThreshold
member.summary: Distance from the sky light at which any geometry should be treated as part of the sky. This is also used by reflection captures, so update reflection captures to see the impact.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.bLowerHemisphereIsBlack
member.summary: Whether all distant lighting from the lower hemisphere should be set to LowerHemisphereColor. Enabling this is accurate when lighting a scene on a planet where the ground blocks the sky, However disabling it can be useful to approximate skylight bounce lighting (eg Movable light).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.OcclusionMaxDistance
member.summary: Max distance that the occlusion of one point will affect another. Higher values increase the cost of Distance Field AO exponentially.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.Contrast
member.summary: Contrast S-curve applied to the computed AO. A value of 0 means no contrast increase, 1 is a significant contrast increase.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.MinOcclusion
member.summary: Controls the darkest that a fully occluded area can get.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USkyLightComponent.OcclusionTint
member.summary: Tint color on occluded areas, artistic control.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.USoundNodeRandom
member.summary: Selects sounds from a random set

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USoundNodeRandom.PreselectAtLevelLoad
member.summary: If greater than 0, then upon each level load such a number of inputs will be randomly selected and the rest will be removed. This can be used to cut down the memory usage of large randomizing cues.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USoundNodeRandom.bRandomizeWithoutReplacement
member.summary: Determines whether or not this SoundNodeRandom should randomize with or without replacement. WithoutReplacement means that only nodes left will be valid for selection. So with that, you are guarenteed to have only one occurrence of the sound played until all of the other sounds in the set have all been played. WithReplacement means that a node will be chosen and then placed back into the set. So one could play the same sound over and over if the probabilities don't go your way :-)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USoundNodeRandom.HasBeenUsed
member.summary: Internal state of which sounds have been played. This is only used at runtime to keep track of which sounds have been played

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USoundNodeRandom.NumRandomUsed
member.summary: Counter var so we don't have to count all of the used sounds each time we choose a sound *

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USoundNodeRandom.PIEHiddenNodes
member.summary: Editor only list of nodes hidden to duplicate behavior of PreselectAtLevelLoad

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent
member.summary: This component tries to maintain its children at a fixed distance from the parent, but will retract the children if there is a collision, and spring back when there is no collision. Example: Use as a 'camera boom' to keep the follow camera for a player from colliding into the world.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.TargetArmLength
member.summary: Natural length of the spring arm when there are no collisions

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.SocketOffset
member.summary: offset at end of spring arm; use this instead of the relative offset of the attached component to ensure the line trace works as desired

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.TargetOffset
member.summary: Offset at start of spring, applied in world space. Use this if you want a world-space offset from the parent component instead of the usual relative-space offset.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.ProbeSize
member.summary: How big should the query probe sphere be (in unreal units)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.ProbeChannel
member.summary: Collision channel of the query probe (defaults to ECC_Camera)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bDoCollisionTest
member.summary: If true, do a collision test using ProbeChannel and ProbeSize to prevent camera clipping into level.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bUsePawnControlRotation
member.summary: If this component is placed on a pawn, should it use the view/control rotation of the pawn where possible? @see APawn::GetViewRotation()

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bInheritPitch
member.summary: Should we inherit pitch from parent component. Does nothing if using Absolute Rotation.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bInheritYaw
member.summary: Should we inherit yaw from parent component. Does nothing if using Absolute Rotation.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bInheritRoll
member.summary: Should we inherit roll from parent component. Does nothing if using Absolute Rotation.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bEnableCameraLag
member.summary: If true, camera lags behind target position to smooth its movement. @see CameraLagSpeed

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bEnableCameraRotationLag
member.summary: If true, camera lags behind target rotation to smooth its movement. @see CameraRotationLagSpeed

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bUseCameraLagSubstepping
member.summary: If bUseCameraLagSubstepping is true, sub-step camera damping so that it handles fluctuating frame rates well (though this comes at a cost). @see CameraLagMaxTimeStep

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.bDrawDebugLagMarkers
member.summary: If true and camera location lag is enabled, draws markers at the camera target (in green) and the lagged position (in yellow). A line is drawn between the two locations, in green normally but in red if the distance to the lag target has been clamped (by CameraLagMaxDistance).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.CameraLagSpeed
member.summary: If bEnableCameraLag is true, controls how quickly camera reaches target position. Low values are slower (more lag), high values are faster (less lag), while zero is instant (no lag).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.CameraRotationLagSpeed
member.summary: If bEnableCameraRotationLag is true, controls how quickly camera reaches target position. Low values are slower (more lag), high values are faster (less lag), while zero is instant (no lag).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.CameraLagMaxTimeStep
member.summary: Max time step used when sub-stepping camera lag.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USpringArmComponent.CameraLagMaxDistance
member.summary: Max distance the camera target may lag behind the current location. If set to zero, no max distance is enforced.

member.summary: If true, the distances at which LODs swap are computed automatically.

member.summary: Minimum LOD to use for rendering. This is the default setting for the mesh and can be overridden by component settings.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.Materials
member.summary: Materials used by this static mesh. Individual sections index in to this array.

member.summary: The light map resolution

member.summary: The light map coordinate index

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.BodySetup
member.summary: Physics data.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.LODForCollision
member.summary: Specifies which mesh LOD to use for complex (per-poly) collision. Sometimes it can be desirable to use a lower poly representation for collision to reduce memory usage, improve performance and behaviour. Collision representation does not change based on distance to camera.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.bUseMaximumStreamingTexelRatio
member.summary: If true, use a less-conservative method of mip LOD texture factor computation. Requires mesh to be resaved to take effect as algorithm is applied on save

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.bStripComplexCollisionForConsole
member.summary: If true, strips unwanted complex collision data aka kDOP tree when cooking for consoles. On the Playstation 3 data of this mesh will be stored in video memory.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.bHasNavigationData
member.summary: If true, mesh will have NavCollision property with additional data for navmesh generation and usage. Set to false for distant meshes (always outside navigation bounds) to save memory on collision data.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.LpvBiasMultiplier
member.summary: Bias multiplier for Light Propagation Volume lighting

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.bAllowCPUAccess
member.summary: If true, will keep geometry data CPU-accessible in cooked builds, rather than uploading to GPU memory and releasing it from CPU memory. This is required if you wish to access StaticMesh geometry data on the CPU at runtime in cooked builds (e.g. to convert StaticMesh to ProceduralMeshComponent)

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.AssetImportData
member.summary: Importing data and options used for this mesh

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.SourceFilePath
member.summary: Path to the resource used to construct this static mesh

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.SourceFileTimestamp
member.summary: Date/Time-stamp of the file from the last import

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.ThumbnailInfo
member.summary: Information for thumbnail rendering

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.EditorCameraPosition
member.summary: The stored camera position to use as a default for the static mesh editor

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.bCustomizedCollision
member.summary: If the user has modified collision in any way or has custom collision imported. Used for determining if to auto generate collision on import

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.Sockets
member.summary: Array of named socket locations, set up in editor and used as a shortcut instead of specifying everything explicitly to AttachComponent in the StaticMeshComponent.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.PositiveBoundsExtension
member.summary: Bound extension values in the positive direction of XYZ, positive value increases bound size

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.NegativeBoundsExtension
member.summary: Bound extension values in the negative direction of XYZ, positive value increases bound size

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.ExtendedBounds

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UStaticMesh.ElementToIgnoreForTexFactor
member.summary: Index of an element to ignore while gathering streaming texture factors. This is useful to disregard automatically generated vertex data which breaks texture factor heuristics.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.USubsurfaceProfile
member.summary: Subsurface Scattering profile asset, can be specified at the material. Only for "Subsurface Profile" materials, is use during Screenspace Subsurface Scattering Don't change at runtime. All properties in here are per material - texture like variations need to come from properties that are in the GBuffer.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.USubUVAnimation
member.summary: SubUV animation asset, which caches bounding geometry for regions in the SubUVTexture with non-zero opacity. Particle emitters with a SubUV module which use this asset leverage the optimal bounding geometry to reduce overdraw.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USubUVAnimation.SubUVTexture
member.summary: Texture to generate bounding geometry from.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USubUVAnimation.SubImages_Horizontal
member.summary: The number of sub-images horizontally in the texture

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USubUVAnimation.SubImages_Vertical
member.summary: The number of sub-images vertically in the texture

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USubUVAnimation.BoundingMode
member.summary: More bounding vertices results in reduced overdraw, but adds more triangle overhead. The eight vertex mode is best used when the SubUV texture has a lot of space to cut out that is not captured by the four vertex version, and when the particles using the texture will be few and large.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.USubUVAnimation.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: Alpha channel values larger than the threshold are considered occupied and will be contained in the bounding geometry. Raising this threshold slightly can reduce overdraw in particles using this animation asset.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UTexture.CompositePower

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UTexture2D.LevelIndex
member.summary: * Level scope index of this texture. It is used to reduce the amount of lookup to map a texture to its level index. * Useful when building texture streaming data, as well as when filling the texture streamer with precomputed data. * It relates to FStreamingTextureBuildInfo::TextureLevelIndex and also the index in ULevel::StreamingTextureGuids. * Default value of -1, indicates that the texture has an unknown index (not yet processed). At level load time, * -2 is also used to indicate that the texture has been processed but no entry were found in the level table. * After any of these processes, the LevelIndex is reset to INDEX_NONE. Making it ready for the next level task.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UTexture2D.FirstResourceMemMip
member.summary: keep track of first mip level used for ResourceMem creation

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UTexture2D.ForceMipLevelsToBeResidentTimestamp

member.summary: Invalidates the widget from the view of a layout caching widget that may own this widget. will force the owning widget to redraw and cache children on the next paint pass.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidget.ForceLayoutPrepass
member.summary: Forces a pre-pass. A pre-pass caches the desired size of the widget hierarchy owned by this widget. One pre-pass is already happens for every widget before Tick occurs. You only need to perform another pre-pass if you are adding child widgets this frame and want them to immediately be visible this frame.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent
member.summary: This is a highly experimental component to allow interaction with the Widget Component. Not everything should be expected to work correctly. This class allows you to simulate a sort of laser pointer device, when it hovers over widgets it will send the basic signals to show as if the mouse were moving on top of it. You'll then tell the component to simulate key presses, like Left Mouse, down and up, to simulate a mouse click.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.SetCustomHitResult(UnrealEngine.FHitResult)
member.summary: Set custom hit result. This is only taken into account if InteractionSource is set to EWidgetInteractionSource::Custom.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.GetLastHitResult
member.summary: Gets the last hit result generated by the component. Returns the custom hit result if that was set.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.IsOverHitTestVisibleWidget
member.summary: Returns true if a widget under the hit result is has a visibility that makes it hit test visible. e.g. Slate widgets that return true for GetVisibility().IsHitTestVisible().

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.IsOverFocusableWidget
member.summary: Returns true if a widget under the hit result is focusable. e.g. Slate widgets that return true for SupportsKeyboardFocus().

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.IsOverInteractableWidget
member.summary: Returns true if a widget under the hit result is interactive. e.g. Slate widgets that return true for IsInteractable().

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.GetHoveredWidgetComponent
member.summary: Get the currently hovered widget component.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.ScrollWheel(System.Single)
member.summary: Sends a scroll wheel event to the widget under the last hit result.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.SendKeyChar(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Transmits a list of characters to a widget by simulating a OnKeyChar event for each key listed in the string.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.PressAndReleaseKey(UnrealEngine.FKey)
member.summary: Does both the press and release of a simulated keyboard key.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.ReleaseKey(UnrealEngine.FKey)
member.summary: Releases a key as if it had been released by the keyboard.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.PressKey(UnrealEngine.FKey,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Press a key as if it had come from the keyboard. Avoid using this for 'a-z|A-Z', things like the Editable Textbox in Slate expect OnKeyChar to be called to signal a specific character being send to the widget. So for those cases you should use SendKeyChar.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.ReleasePointerKey(UnrealEngine.FKey)
member.summary: Releases a key as if the mouse/pointer were the source of it. Normally you would just use Left/Right mouse button for the Key. However - advanced uses could also be imagined where you send other keys to signal widgets to take special actions if they're under the cursor.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.PressPointerKey(UnrealEngine.FKey)
member.summary: Presses a key as if the mouse/pointer were the source of it. Normally you would just use Left/Right mouse button for the Key. However - advanced uses could also be imagined where you send other keys to signal widgets to take special actions if they're under the cursor.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.OnHoveredWidgetChanged
member.summary: Called when the hovered Widget Component changes. The interaction component functions at the Slate level - so it's unable to report anything about what UWidget is under the hit result.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.VirtualUserIndex
member.summary: Represents the Virtual User Index. Each virtual user should be represented by a different index number, this will maintain separate capture and focus states for them. Each controller or finger-tip should get a unique PointerIndex.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.PointerIndex
member.summary: Each user virtual controller or virtual finger tips being simulated should use a different pointer index.

member.summary: The distance in game units the component should be able to interact with a widget component.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.UWidgetInteractionComponent.InteractionSource
member.summary: Should we project from the world location of the component? If you set this to false, you'll need to call SetCustomHitResult(), and provide the result of a custom hit test form whatever location you wish.

member.summary: Should the interaction component perform hit testing (Automatic or Custom) and attempt to simulate hover - if you were going to emulate a keyboard you would want to turn this option off if the virtual keyboard was separate from the virtual pointer device and used a second interaction component.

member.name: M:UnrealEngine.UWidgetLayoutLibrary.GetMousePositionScaledByDPI(UnrealEngine.APlayerController,System.Single@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Gets the mouse position of the player controller, scaled by the DPI. If you're trying to go from raw mouse screenspace coordinates to fullscreen widget space, you'll need to transform the mouse into DPI Scaled space. This function performs that scaling. MousePositionScaledByDPI = MousePosition * (1 / ViewportScale).

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.UWorld
member.summary: The World is the top level object representing a map or a sandbox in which Actors and Components will exist and be rendered. A World can be a single Persistent Level with an optional list of streaming levels that are loaded and unloaded via volumes and blueprint functions or it can be a collection of levels organized with a World Composition. In a standalone game, generally only a single World exists except during seamless area transitions when both a destination and current world exists. In the editor many Worlds exist: The level being edited, each PIE instance, each editor tool which has an interactive rendered viewport, and many more.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FAnimLinkableElement
member.summary: Used to describe an element that can be linked to a segment in a montage or sequence. Usage: Inherit from FAnimLinkableElement and make sure to call LinkMontage or LinkSequence both on creation and on loading the element. From there SetTime and GetTime should be used to control where this element is in the montage or sequence. For more advanced usage, see this implementation used in FAnimNotifyEvent where we have a secondary link to handle a duration @see FAnimNotifyEvent

member.summary: Whether or not listener-focus calculations are enabled for this attenuation.

member.summary: Whether or not to enable complex geometry occlusion checks.

member.summary: The type of volume versus distance algorithm to use for the attenuation model.

member.summary: The shape of the attenuation volume.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.dBAttenuationAtMax
member.summary: The volume at maximum distance in deciBels.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.OmniRadius
member.summary: At what distance we start treating the sound source as spatialized

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.StereoSpread
member.summary: The distance between left and right stereo channels when stereo assets spatialized.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.SpatializationAlgorithm
member.summary: Which spatialization algorithm to use if spatializing mono sources.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.AttenuationShapeExtents
member.summary: The dimensions to use for the attenuation shape. Interpretation of the values differ per shape. Sphere - X is Sphere Radius. Y and Z are unused Capsule - X is Capsule Half Height, Y is Capsule Radius, Z is unused Box - X, Y, and Z are the Box's dimensions Cone - X is Cone Radius, Y is Cone Angle, Z is Cone Falloff Angle

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.ConeOffset
member.summary: The distance back from the sound's origin to begin the cone when using the cone attenuation shape.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.FalloffDistance
member.summary: The distance over which falloff occurs.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.LPFRadiusMin
member.summary: The range at which to start applying a low pass filter.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.LPFRadiusMax
member.summary: The range at which to apply the maximum amount of low pass filter.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.LPFFrequencyAtMin
member.summary: The Frequency in hertz at which to set the LPF when the sound is at LPFRadiusMin. (defaults to bypass)

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.LPFFrequencyAtMax
member.summary: The Frequency in hertz at which to set the LPF when the sound is at LPFRadiusMax.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.FocusAzimuth
member.summary: Azimuth angle (in degrees) relative to the listener forward vector which defines the focus region of sounds. Sounds playing at an angle less than this will be in focus.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.NonFocusAzimuth
member.summary: Azimuth angle (in degrees) relative to the listener forward vector which defines the non-focus region of sounds. Sounds playing at an angle greater than this will be out of focus.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.FocusDistanceScale
member.summary: Amount to scale the distance calculation of sounds that are in-focus. Can be used to make in-focus sounds appear to be closer or further away than they actually are.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.NonFocusDistanceScale
member.summary: Amount to scale the distance calculation of sounds that are not in-focus. Can be used to make in-focus sounds appear to be closer or further away than they actually are.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.FocusPriorityScale
member.summary: Amount to scale the priority of sounds that are in focus. Can be used to boost the priority of sounds that are in focus.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.NonFocusPriorityScale
member.summary: Amount to scale the priority of sounds that are not in-focus. Can be used to reduce the priority of sounds that are not in focus.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.FocusVolumeAttenuation
member.summary: Amount to attenuate sounds that are in focus. Can be overridden at the sound-level.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.NonFocusVolumeAttenuation
member.summary: Amount to attenuate sounds that are not in focus. Can be overridden at the sound-level.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.OcclusionTraceChannel
member.summary: Which trace channel to use for audio occlusion checks.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.OcclusionLowPassFilterFrequency
member.summary: The low pass filter frequency (in hertz) to apply if the sound playing in this audio component is occluded. This will override the frequency set in LowPassFilterFrequency. A frequency of 0.0 is the device sample rate and will bypass the filter.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.OcclusionVolumeAttenuation
member.summary: The amount of volume attenuation to apply to sounds which are occluded.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FAttenuationSettings.OcclusionInterpolationTime
member.summary: The amount of time in seconds to interpolate to the target OcclusionLowPassFilterFrequency when a sound is occluded.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FBodyInstance.CollisionEnabled
member.summary: Type of collision enabled. No Collision : Will not create any representation in the physics engine. Cannot be used for spatial queries (raycasts, sweeps, overlaps) or simulation (rigid body, constraints). Best performance possible (especially for moving objects) Query Only : Only used for spatial queries (raycasts, sweeps, and overlaps). Cannot be used for simulation (rigid body, constraints). Useful for character movement and things that do not need physical simulation. Performance gains by keeping data out of simulation tree. Physics Only : Only used only for physics simulation (rigid body, constraints). Cannot be used for spatial queries (raycasts, sweeps, overlaps). Useful for jiggly bits on characters that do not need per bone detection. Performance gains by keeping data out of query tree Collision Enabled : Can be used for both spatial queries (raycasts, sweeps, overlaps) and simulation (rigid body, constraints).

member.summary: A mass scaling that is applied to the cloth. Corresponds to 100X the MotionAdaptation parameter in autodesk plugin.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FClothPhysicsProperties.InertiaBlend
member.summary: Amount of inertia that is kept when using local space simulation. Internal name is inertia scale

member.summary: Minimal amount of distance particles will keep of each other.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FClothPhysicsProperties.SelfCollisionSquashScale
member.summary: unclear what this actually does.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FClothPhysicsProperties.SelfCollisionStiffness
member.summary: Self collision stiffness. 0 off, 1 for on.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FClothPhysicsProperties.SolverFrequency
member.summary: A computation parameter for the Solver. Along with frame rate this probably specifies the number of solver iterations

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FClothPhysicsProperties.FiberCompression
member.summary: Lower (compression) Limit of SoftZone (relative to rest length). Applied for all fiber types. If both compression and expansion are 1.0 then there is no deadzone.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FClothPhysicsProperties.FiberExpansion
member.summary: Upper (expansion) Limit of SoftZone (relative to rest length). Applied to all fiber types. Also referred to as "stretch" range by apex internally.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FClothPhysicsProperties.FiberResistance
member.summary: Resistance Multiplier that's applied to within SoftZone amount for all fiber types. 0.0 for a complete deadzone (no force). At 1.0 the spring response within the softzone is as stiff it is elsewhere. This parameter also known as scale by Apex internally.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FCollisionResponseContainer.GameTraceChannel1
member.summary: in order to use this custom channels we recommend to define in your local file - i.e. #define COLLISION_WEAPON ECC_GameTraceChannel1 and make sure you customize these it in INI file by in DefaultEngine.ini [/Script/Engine.CollisionProfile] GameTraceChannel1="Weapon" also in the INI file, you can override collision profiles that are defined by simply redefining note that Weapon isn't defined in the BaseEngine.ini file, but "Trigger" is defined in Engine +Profiles=(Name="Trigger",CollisionEnabled=QueryOnly,ObjectTypeName=WorldDynamic, DefaultResponse=ECR_Overlap, CustomResponses=((Channel=Visibility, Response=ECR_Ignore), (Channel=Weapon, Response=ECR_Ignore)))

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.Swing1LimitDegrees
member.summary: Angle of movement along the XY plane. This defines the first symmetric angle of the cone.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.Swing2LimitDegrees
member.summary: Angle of movement along the XZ plane. This defines the second symmetric angle of the cone.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.Swing1Motion
member.summary: Indicates whether the Swing1 limit is used.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.Swing2Motion
member.summary: Indicates whether the Swing2 limit is used.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.Stiffness
member.summary: Stiffness of the soft constraint. Only used when Soft Constraint is on.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.Damping
member.summary: Damping of the soft constraint. Only used when Soft Constraint is on.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.Restitution
member.summary: Controls the amount of bounce when the constraint is violated. A restitution value of 1 will bounce back with the same velocity the limit was hit. A value of 0 will stop dead.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.ContactDistance
member.summary: Determines how close to the limit we have to get before turning the joint on. Larger value will be more expensive, but will do a better job not violating constraints. A smaller value will be more efficient, but easier to violate.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FConeConstraint.bSoftConstraint
member.summary: Whether we want to use a soft constraint (spring).

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FConstraintProfileProperties.bEnableProjection
member.summary: If distance error between bodies exceeds 0.1 units, or rotation error exceeds 10 degrees, body will be projected to fix this. For example a chain spinning too fast will have its elements appear detached due to velocity, this will project all bodies so they still appear attached to each other.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleAdvancedParameters
member.summary: Parameters that are less-often used.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleAdvancedParameters.DamageCap
member.summary: Limits the amount of damage applied to a chunk. This is useful for preventing the entire destructible from getting pulverized by a very large application of damage. This can easily happen when impact damage is used, and the damage amount is proportional to the impact force (see forceToDamage).

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleAdvancedParameters.ImpactVelocityThreshold
member.summary: Large impact force may be reported if rigid bodies are spawned inside one another. In this case the realative velocity of the two objects will be low. This variable allows the user to set a minimum velocity threshold for impacts to ensure that the objects are moving at a min velocity in order for the impact force to be considered.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleAdvancedParameters.MaxChunkSpeed
member.summary: If greater than 0, the chunks' speeds will not be allowed to exceed this value. Use 0 to disable this feature (this is the default).

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleAdvancedParameters.FractureImpulseScale
member.summary: Scale factor used to apply an impulse force along the normal of chunk when fractured. This is used in order to "push" the pieces out as they fracture.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleChunkParameters
member.summary: Per-chunk authoring data.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleChunkParameters.bIsSupportChunk
member.summary: Defines the chunk to be environmentally supported, if the appropriate NxDestructibleParametersFlag flags are set in NxDestructibleParameters. Default = false.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleChunkParameters.bDoNotFracture
member.summary: Defines the chunk to be unfractureable. If this is true, then none of its children will be fractureable. Default = false.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleChunkParameters.bDoNotDamage
member.summary: Defines the chunk to be undamageable. This means this chunk will not fracture, but its children might. Default = false.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleChunkParameters.bDoNotCrumble
member.summary: Defines the chunk to be uncrumbleable. This means this chunk will not be broken down into fluid mesh particles no matter how much damage it takes. Note: this only applies to chunks with no children. For a chunk with children, then: 1) The chunk may be broken down into its children, and then its children may be crumbled, if the doNotCrumble flag is not set on them. 2) If the Destructible module's chunk depth offset LOD may be set such that this chunk effectively has no children. In this case, the doNotCrumble flag will apply to it. Default = false.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDamageParameters
member.summary: Parameters that pertain to chunk damage.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDamageParameters.DamageThreshold
member.summary: The damage amount which will cause a chunk to fracture (break free).

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDamageParameters.DamageSpread
member.summary: Controls how easily damage spreads. DamageRadius = Damage*DamageSpread. All chunks within DamageRadius will take damage. Full damage is taken at zero distance, and zero damage at the DamageRadius.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDamageParameters.bEnableImpactDamage
member.summary: Whether to apply damage to destructible when colliding with an object. @see ImpactDamage

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDamageParameters.ImpactDamage
member.summary: Controls how much damage is applied upon collision. Damage = ImpactDamage * ImpactForce. @see DepthParameters for per level control of ImpactDamage

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDamageParameters.DefaultImpactDamageDepth
member.summary: Max depth level where impact damage is enabled. @see DepthParameters for per level control of ImpactDamage If negative, impact damage is disabled

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDamageParameters.bCustomImpactResistance
member.summary: By default, objects that collide with destructibles will bounce back. Custom resistance allows for finer control of how much a destructible "pushes back" against a colliding object. @see ImpactResistance

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDamageParameters.ImpactResistance
member.summary: Controls how much resistance is applied to colliding objects. Weak materials like glass should set this to a low value so that objects will pass right through them during fracture. @see DepthParameters for per level control of ImpactResistance

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDebrisParameters
member.summary: Parameters that pertain to chunk debris-level settings.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDebrisParameters.ValidBounds
member.summary: "Debris chunks" (see debrisDepth, above) will be destroyed if they leave this box. The box translates with the destructible actor's initial position, but does not rotate or scale.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDepthParameters
member.summary: Properties that may be set for all chunks at a particular depth in the fracture hierarchy.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleDepthParameters.ImpactDamageOverride
member.summary: Chunks up to the depth DefaultImpactDamageDepth will take impact damage, unless one of the override options (see EImpactDamageOverride) is chosen.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParameters
member.summary: Parameters that apply to a destructible actor.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParameters.DamageParameters
member.summary: Parameters that pertain to chunk damage. See DestructibleDamageParameters.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParameters.DebrisParameters
member.summary: Parameters that pertain to chunk debris-level settings. See DestructibleDebrisParameters.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParameters.AdvancedParameters
member.summary: Parameters that are less-often used. See DestructibleAdvancedParameters.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParameters.SpecialHierarchyDepths
member.summary: Special hierarchy depths for various behaviors.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParameters.DepthParameters
member.summary: Parameters that apply to every chunk at a given level. the element [0] of the array applies to the level 0 (unfractured) chunk, element [1] applies to the level 1 chunks, etc.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParameters.Flags
member.summary: A collection of flags defined in DestructibleParametersFlag.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag
member.summary: Flags that apply to a destructible actor.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bAccumulateDamage
member.summary: If set, chunks will "remember" damage applied to them, so that many applications of a damage amount below damageThreshold will eventually fracture the chunk. If not set, a single application of damage must exceed damageThreshold in order to fracture the chunk.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bAssetDefinedSupport
member.summary: If set, then chunks which are tagged as "support" chunks (via NxDestructibleChunkDesc::isSupportChunk) will have environmental support in static destructibles. Note: if both bAssetDefinedSupport and bWorldSupport are set, then chunks must be tagged as "support" chunks AND overlap the NxScene's static geometry in order to be environmentally supported.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bWorldSupport
member.summary: If set, then chunks which overlap the NxScene's static geometry will have environmental support in static destructibles. Note: if both bAssetDefinedSupport and bWorldSupport are set, then chunks must be tagged as "support" chunks AND overlap the NxScene's static geometry in order to be environmentally supported.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bDebrisTimeout
member.summary: Whether or not chunks at or deeper than the "debris" depth (see NxDestructibleParameters::debrisDepth) will time out. The lifetime is a value between NxDestructibleParameters::debrisLifetimeMin and NxDestructibleParameters::debrisLifetimeMax, based upon the destructible module's LOD setting.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bDebrisMaxSeparation
member.summary: Whether or not chunks at or deeper than the "debris" depth (see NxDestructibleParameters::debrisDepth) will be removed if they separate too far from their origins. The maxSeparation is a value between NxDestructibleParameters::debrisMaxSeparationMin and NxDestructibleParameters::debrisMaxSeparationMax, based upon the destructible module's LOD setting.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bCrumbleSmallestChunks
member.summary: If set, the smallest chunks may be further broken down, either by fluid crumbles (if a crumble particle system is specified in the NxDestructibleActorDesc), or by simply removing the chunk if no crumble particle system is specified. Note: the "smallest chunks" are normally defined to be the deepest level of the fracture hierarchy. However, they may be taken from higher levels of the hierarchy if NxModuleDestructible::setMaxChunkDepthOffset is called with a non-zero value.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bAccurateRaycasts
member.summary: If set, the NxDestructibleActor::rayCast function will search within the nearest visible chunk hit for collisions with child chunks. This is used to get a better raycast position and normal, in case the parent collision volume does not tightly fit the graphics mesh. The returned chunk index will always be that of the visible parent that is intersected, however.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bUseValidBounds
member.summary: If set, the ValidBounds field of NxDestructibleParameters will be used. These bounds are translated (but not scaled or rotated) to the origin of the destructible actor. If a chunk or chunk island moves outside of those bounds, it is destroyed.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleParametersFlag.bFormExtendedStructures
member.summary: If initially static, the destructible will become part of an extended support structure if it is in contact with another static destructible that also has this flag set.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleSpecialHierarchyDepths
member.summary: Special hierarchy depths for various behaviors.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleSpecialHierarchyDepths.SupportDepth
member.summary: The chunk hierarchy depth at which to create a support graph. Higher depth levels give more detailed support, but will give a higher computational load. Chunks below the support depth will never be supported.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleSpecialHierarchyDepths.MinimumFractureDepth
member.summary: The chunks will not be broken free below this depth.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleSpecialHierarchyDepths.bEnableDebris
member.summary: Enables debris at a specific depth level. @see DebrisDepth

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleSpecialHierarchyDepths.DebrisDepth
member.summary: The hierarchy depth at which chunks are considered to be "debris."

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FDestructibleSpecialHierarchyDepths.EssentialDepth
member.summary: The chunk hierarchy depth up to which chunks will always be processed. These chunks are considered to be essential either for gameplay or visually. The minimum value is 0, meaning the level 0 chunk is always considered essential. Default value is 0.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FHitResult
member.summary: Structure containing information about one hit of a trace, such as point of impact and surface normal at that point.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.bBlockingHit
member.summary: Indicates if this hit was a result of blocking collision. If false, there was no hit or it was an overlap/touch instead.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.bStartPenetrating
member.summary: Whether the trace started in penetration, i.e. with an initial blocking overlap. In the case of penetration, if PenetrationDepth > 0.f, then it will represent the distance along the Normal vector that will result in minimal contact between the swept shape and the object that was hit. In this case, ImpactNormal will be the normal opposed to movement at that location (ie, Normal may not equal ImpactNormal). ImpactPoint will be the same as Location, since there is no single impact point to report.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.Time
member.summary: 'Time' of impact along trace direction (ranging from 0.0 to 1.0) if there is a hit, indicating time between TraceStart and TraceEnd. For swept movement (but not queries) this may be pulled back slightly from the actual time of impact, to prevent precision problems with adjacent geometry.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.Distance
member.summary: The distance from the TraceStart to the ImpactPoint in world space. This value is 0 if there was an initial overlap (trace started inside another colliding object).

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.Location
member.summary: The location in world space where the moving shape would end up against the impacted object, if there is a hit. Equal to the point of impact for line tests. Example: for a sphere trace test, this is the point where the center of the sphere would be located when it touched the other object. For swept movement (but not queries) this may not equal the final location of the shape since hits are pulled back slightly to prevent precision issues from overlapping another surface.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.ImpactPoint
F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.Normal
member.summary: Normal of the hit in world space, for the object that was swept. Equal to ImpactNormal for line tests. This is computed for capsules and spheres, otherwise it will be the same as ImpactNormal. Example: for a sphere trace test, this is a normalized vector pointing in towards the center of the sphere at the point of impact.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.ImpactNormal
member.summary: Normal of the hit in world space, for the object that was hit by the sweep, if any. For example if a box hits a flat plane, this is a normalized vector pointing out from the plane. In the case of impact with a corner or edge of a surface, usually the "most opposing" normal (opposed to the query direction) is chosen.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.TraceStart
member.summary: Start location of the trace. For example if a sphere is swept against the world, this is the starting location of the center of the sphere.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.TraceEnd

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FHitResult.PenetrationDepth

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings
member.summary: Per-object settings for Lightmass

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.bUseTwoSidedLighting
member.summary: If true, this object will be lit as if it receives light from both sides of its polygons.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.bShadowIndirectOnly
member.summary: If true, this object will only shadow indirect lighting.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.bUseEmissiveForStaticLighting
member.summary: If true, allow using the emissive for static lighting.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.bUseVertexNormalForHemisphereGather
member.summary: Typically the triangle normal is used for hemisphere gathering which prevents incorrect self-shadowing from artist-tweaked vertex normals. However in the case of foliage whose vertex normal has been setup to match the underlying terrain, gathering in the direction of the vertex normal is desired.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.EmissiveLightFalloffExponent
member.summary: Direct lighting falloff exponent for mesh area lights created from emissive areas on this primitive.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.EmissiveLightExplicitInfluenceRadius
member.summary: Direct lighting influence radius. The default is 0, which means the influence radius should be automatically generated based on the emissive light brightness. Values greater than 0 override the automatic method.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.EmissiveBoost
member.summary: Scales the emissive contribution of all materials applied to this object.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.DiffuseBoost
member.summary: Scales the diffuse contribution of all materials applied to this object.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassPrimitiveSettings.FullyOccludedSamplesFraction
member.summary: Fraction of samples taken that must be occluded in order to reach full occlusion.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.StaticLightingLevelScale
member.summary: Warning: Setting this to less than 1 will greatly increase build times! Scale of the level relative to real world scale (1 Unreal Unit = 1 cm). All scale-dependent Lightmass setting defaults have been tweaked to work well with real world scale, Any levels with a different scale should use this scale to compensate. For large levels it can drastically reduce build times to set this to 2 or 4.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.NumIndirectLightingBounces
member.summary: Number of times light is allowed to bounce off of surfaces, starting from the light source. 0 is direct lighting only, 1 is one bounce, etc. Bounce 1 takes the most time to calculate and contributes the most to visual quality, followed by bounce 2. Successive bounces don't really affect build times, but have a much lower visual impact.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.IndirectLightingQuality
member.summary: Warning: Setting this higher than 1 will greatly increase build times! Can be used to increase the GI solver sample counts in order to get higher quality for levels that need it. It can be useful to reduce IndirectLightingSmoothness somewhat (~.75) when increasing quality to get defined indirect shadows. Note that this can't affect compression artifacts, UV seams or other texture based artifacts.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.IndirectLightingSmoothness
member.summary: Smoothness factor to apply to indirect lighting. This is useful in some lighting conditions when Lightmass cannot resolve accurate indirect lighting. 1 is default smoothness tweaked for a variety of lighting situations. Higher values like 3 smooth out the indirect lighting more, but at the cost of indirect shadows losing detail.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.EnvironmentColor
member.summary: Represents a constant color light surrounding the upper hemisphere of the level, like a sky. This light source currently does not get bounced as indirect lighting.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.EnvironmentIntensity
member.summary: Scales EnvironmentColor to allow independent color and brightness controls.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.EmissiveBoost
member.summary: Scales the emissive contribution of all materials in the scene. Currently disabled and should be removed with mesh area lights.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.DiffuseBoost
member.summary: Scales the diffuse contribution of all materials in the scene.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.bUseAmbientOcclusion
member.summary: If true, AmbientOcclusion will be enabled.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.bGenerateAmbientOcclusionMaterialMask
member.summary: Whether to generate textures storing the AO computed by Lightmass. These can be accessed through the PrecomputedAOMask material node, Which is useful for blending between material layers on environment assets. Be sure to set DirectIlluminationOcclusionFraction and IndirectIlluminationOcclusionFraction to 0 if you only want the PrecomputedAOMask!

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.DirectIlluminationOcclusionFraction
member.summary: How much of the AO to apply to direct lighting.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.IndirectIlluminationOcclusionFraction
member.summary: How much of the AO to apply to indirect lighting.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.OcclusionExponent
member.summary: Higher exponents increase contrast.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.FullyOccludedSamplesFraction
member.summary: Fraction of samples taken that must be occluded in order to reach full occlusion.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.MaxOcclusionDistance
member.summary: Maximum distance for an object to cause occlusion on another object.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.bVisualizeMaterialDiffuse
member.summary: If true, override normal direct and indirect lighting with just the exported diffuse term.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.bVisualizeAmbientOcclusion
member.summary: If true, override normal direct and indirect lighting with just the AO term.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.VolumeLightSamplePlacementScale
member.summary: Scales the distances at which volume lighting samples are placed. Volume lighting samples are computed by Lightmass and are used for GI on movable components. Using larger scales results in less sample memory usage and reduces Indirect Lighting Cache update times, but less accurate transitions between lighting areas.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLightmassWorldInfoSettings.bCompressLightmaps
member.summary: Whether to compress lightmap textures. Disabling lightmap texture compression will reduce artifacts but increase memory and disk size by 4x. Use caution when disabling this.

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FLinearColor
member.summary: A linear color. The full C++ class is located here: Engine\Source\Runtime\Core\Public\Math\Color.h

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint
member.summary: Distance constraint

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.Limit
member.summary: The distance allowed between between the two joint reference frames. Distance applies on all axes enabled (one axis means line, two axes implies circle, three axes implies sphere)

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.XMotion
member.summary: Indicates the linear constraint applied along the X-axis. Free implies no constraint at all. Locked implies no movement along X is allowed. Limited implies the distance in the joint along all active axes must be less than the Distance provided.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.YMotion
member.summary: Indicates the linear constraint applied along the X-axis. Free implies no constraint at all. Locked implies no movement along X is allowed. Limited implies the distance in the joint along all active axes must be less than the Distance provided.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.ZMotion
member.summary: Indicates the linear constraint applied along the X-axis. Free implies no constraint at all. Locked implies no movement along X is allowed. Limited implies the distance in the joint along all active axes must be less than the Distance provided.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.Stiffness
member.summary: Stiffness of the soft constraint. Only used when Soft Constraint is on.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.Damping
member.summary: Damping of the soft constraint. Only used when Soft Constraint is on.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.Restitution
member.summary: Controls the amount of bounce when the constraint is violated. A restitution value of 1 will bounce back with the same velocity the limit was hit. A value of 0 will stop dead.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.ContactDistance
member.summary: Determines how close to the limit we have to get before turning the joint on. Larger value will be more expensive, but will do a better job not violating constraints. A smaller value will be more efficient, but easier to violate.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FLinearConstraint.bSoftConstraint
member.summary: Whether we want to use a soft constraint (spring).

member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FMatrix
member.summary: * A 4x4 matrix. * The full C++ class is located here: Engine\Source\Runtime\Core\Public\Math\Matrix.h

members.member: This isn't applying SCALE, just multiplying float to all members - i.e. weighting
Transform a location - will take into account translation part of the FMatrix.
Inverts the matrix and then transforms V - correctly handles scaling in this matrix.

Transform a direction vector - will not take into account translation part of the FMatrix. If you want to transform a surface normal (or plane) and correctly account for non-uniform scaling you should use TransformByUsingAdjointT.

Transform a direction vector by the inverse of this matrix - will not take into account translation part. If you want to transform a surface normal (or plane) and correctly account for non-uniform scaling you should use TransformByUsingAdjointT with adjoint of matrix inverse.
@return the determinant of rotation 3x3 matrix
Fast path, doesn't check for nil matrices in final release builds
Fast path, and handles nil matrices.
Remove any scaling from this matrix (ie magnitude of each row is 1) and return the 3D scale vector that was initially present with error Tolerance
return a 3D scale vector calculated from this matrix (where each component is the magnitude of a row vector) with error Tolerance.
Returns a matrix with an additional translation concatenated.
Scale the translation part of the matrix by the supplied vector.
@return the maximum magnitude of any row of the matrix.
Apply Scale to this matrix *
@return rotator representation of this matrix

Transform a rotation matrix into a quaternion.
@warning rotation part will need to be unit length for this to be right!
@param OutPlane the near plane of the Frustum of this matrix
@param OutPlane the far plane of the Frustum of this matrix
@param OutPlane the left plane of the Frustum of this matrix
@param OutPlane the right plane of the Frustum of this matrix
@param OutPlane the top plane of the Frustum of this matrix
@param OutPlane the bottom plane of the Frustum of this matrix
Utility for mirroring this transform across a certain plane, and flipping one of the axis as well.

Get a textual representation of the vector.
@return Text describing the vector.

member.summary: If true, degenerate triangles will be removed.

member.summary: Required to optimize mesh in mirrored transform. Double index buffer size.

member.summary: If true, Tangents will be stored at 16 bit vs 8 bit precision.

member.summary: If true, UVs will be stored at full floating point precision.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FMeshBuildSettings.DistanceFieldResolutionScale
member.summary: Scale to apply to the mesh when allocating the distance field volume texture. The default scale is 1, which is assuming that the mesh will be placed unscaled in the world.

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FMeshBuildSettings.bGenerateDistanceFieldAsIfTwoSided
member.summary: Whether to generate the distance field treating every triangle hit as a front face. When enabled prevents the distance field from being discarded due to the mesh being open, but also lowers Distance Field AO quality.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.Bloom2Size

member.summary: AmbientCubemap tint color

member.summary: To scale the Ambient cubemap brightness >=0: off, 1(default), >1 brighter

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AutoExposureMethod
member.summary: The Ambient cubemap (Affects diffuse and specular shading), blends additively which if different from all other settings here
Luminance computation method

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AutoExposureMinBrightness
member.summary: A good value should be positive near 0. This is the minimum brightness the auto exposure can adapt to. It should be tweaked in a dark lighting situation (too small: image appears too bright, too large: image appears too dark). Note: Tweaking emissive materials and lights or tweaking auto exposure can look the same. Tweaking auto exposure has global effect and defined the HDR range - you don't want to change that late in the project development. Eye Adaptation is disabled if MinBrightness = MaxBrightness

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AutoExposureMaxBrightness
member.summary: A good value should be positive (2 is a good value). This is the maximum brightness the auto exposure can adapt to. It should be tweaked in a bright lighting situation (too small: image appears too bright, too large: image appears too dark). Note: Tweaking emissive materials and lights or tweaking auto exposure can look the same. Tweaking auto exposure has global effect and defined the HDR range - you don't want to change that late in the project development. Eye Adaptation is disabled if MinBrightness = MaxBrightness

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AutoExposureBias
member.summary: Logarithmic adjustment for the exposure. Only used if a tonemapper is specified. 0: no adjustment, -1:2x darker, -2:4x darker, 1:2x brighter, 2:4x brighter, ...

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.HistogramLogMin
member.summary: temporary exposed until we found good values, -8: 1/256, -10: 1/1024

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.HistogramLogMax
member.summary: temporary exposed until we found good values 4: 16, 8: 256

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.LensFlareIntensity

member.summary: Tint color for the image based lens flares.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.LensFlareBokehSize

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.LensFlareThreshold

RGB defines the lens flare color, A it's position. This is a temporary solution.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.VignetteIntensity

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.GrainJitter
member.summary: 0..1 grain jitter

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.GrainIntensity
member.summary: 0..1 grain intensity

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionIntensity

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionStaticFraction
member.summary: 0..1 0=no effect on static lighting .. 1=AO affects the stat lighting, 0 is free meaning no extra rendering pass

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionRadius
member.summary: >0, in unreal units, bigger values means even distant surfaces affect the ambient occlusion

member.name: P:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionRadiusInWS
member.summary: true: AO radius is in world space units, false: AO radius is locked the view space in 400 units

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionFadeDistance
member.summary: >0, in unreal units, at what distance the AO effect disppears in the distance (avoding artifacts and AO effects on huge object)

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionFadeRadius
member.summary: >0, in unreal units, how many units before AmbientOcclusionFadeOutDistance it starts fading out

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionDistance
member.summary: >0, in unreal units, how wide the ambient occlusion effect should affect the geometry (in depth), will be removed - only used for non normal method which is not exposed

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionPower
member.summary: >0, in unreal units, bigger values means even distant surfaces affect the ambient occlusion

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionBias
member.summary: >0, in unreal units, default (3.0) works well for flat surfaces but can reduce details

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionQuality
member.summary: 0=lowest quality..100=maximum quality, only a few quality levels are implemented, no soft transition

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionMipBlend

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionMipScale
member.summary: Affects the radius AO radius scale over the multiple mips (lower resolution versions)

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.AmbientOcclusionMipThreshold
member.summary: to tweak the bilateral upsampling when using multiple mips (lower resolution versions)

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FPostProcessSettings.IndirectLightingColor

members.member: Convert a Quaternion into floating-point Euler angles (in degrees).

Get the length of this quaternion.

Enforce that the delta between this Quaternion and another one represents the shortest possible rotation angle
Get the forward direction (X axis) after it has been rotated by this Quaternion.
Get the right direction (Y axis) after it has been rotated by this Quaternion.
Get the up direction (Z axis) after it has been rotated by this Quaternion.

Get the FRotator representation of this Quaternion.

Get the axis of rotation of the Quaternion. This is the axis around which rotation occurs to transform the canonical coordinate system to the target orientation. For the identity Quaternion which has no such rotation, FVector(1,0,0) is returned.

@return Text describing the vector.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FRootMotionSourceGroup.LastPreAdditiveVelocity
member.summary: Saved off pre-additive-applied Velocity, used for being able to reliably add/remove additive velocity from currently computed Velocity (otherwise we would be removing additive velocity that no longer exists, like if you run into a wall and your Velocity becomes 0 - subtracting the velocity that we added heading into the wall last tick would make you go backwards. member.name: T:UnrealEngine.FStreamingTextureBuildInfo
member.summary: This struct holds the result of TextureStreaming Build for each component texture, as referred by its used materials. It is possible that the entry referred by this data is not actually relevant in a given quality / target. It is also possible that some texture are not referred, and will then fall on fallbacks computation. Because each component holds its precomputed data for each texture, this struct is designed to be as compact as possible.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FStreamingTextureBuildInfo.PackedRelativeBox
member.summary: The relative bounding box for this entry. The relative bounds is a bound equal or smaller than the component bounds and represent the merged LOD section bounds of all LOD section referencing the given texture. When the level transform is modified following a call to ApplyLevelTransform, this relative bound becomes deprecated as it was computed from the transform at build time.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FStreamingTextureBuildInfo.TextureLevelIndex
member.summary: The level scope identifier of the texture. When building the texture streaming data, each level holds a list of all referred texture Guids. This is required to prevent loading textures on platforms which would not require the texture to be loaded, and is a consequence of the texture streaming build not being platform specific (the same streaming data is build for every platform target). Could also apply to quality level.

member.name: F:UnrealEngine.FStreamingTextureBuildInfo.TexelFactor
member.summary: The texel factor for this texture. This represent the world size a texture square holding with unit UVs. This value is a combination of the TexelFactor from the mesh and also the material scale. It does not take into consideration StreamingDistanceMultiplier, or texture group scale.
